page.title: Al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani

revision.text:
{{Infobox royalty | name = Sheikha Al-Mayassa | full name = Al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani | title = Sheikha of Qatar | image = CFK & Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani.jpg | caption = Sheikha in left | spouse =Sheikh Jassim bin Abdul Aziz Al-Thani
(m. 2006) | issue = Sheikh Mohammed bin Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani
Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani
Sheikh Abdulaziz bin Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani
Sheikha Norah bint Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1983}} | birth_place = [[Doha]], Qatar | house = [[House of Thani|Thani]] | father = [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani|Sheikh Hamad I bin Khalifa Al Thani, Emir of Qatar]] | mother = [[Moza bint Nasser|Mozah bint Nasser Al Missned]] | occupation = Founder and Chairperson of [[Qatar Museums]], [[Doha Film Institute]] }} '''[[Sheikh#For women|Sheikha]] Al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani''' (born 1983)[http://www.royalark.net/Qatar/qatar7.htm Royal Ark] is the sister of [[Qatar]]'s ruling Emir [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]], and daughter of the country's Father Emir [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]] and former First Lady [[Moza bint Nasser]]. Al-Mayassa was declared the most influential person in art on [[ArtReview]]'s Power 100,[http://artreview.com/power_100 Power 100] and prominently appears on the [[Time 100]],{{cite news|url=http://time.com/70911/sheika-al-mayassa-2014-time-100 |author=Takashi Murakami |title=Sheika al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani |publisher=Time.com |date=2014-04-23 |accessdate=2014-05-13}} and Forbes' The World's 100 Most Powerful Women.{{cite web|url=http://www.qma.com.qa/en/about-us0/board-of-trustees |title=Board of Trustees |publisher=Qatar Museum Authority |accessdate=2014-05-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424162941/http://www.qma.com.qa/en/about-us0/board-of-trustees |archivedate=24 April 2014 }} Al-Mayassa serves as Chairperson of [[Qatar Museums Authority|Qatar Museums]], and it was reported by [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] that her annual acquisition budget on behalf of the organization is estimated at $1 billion.{{cite news|last=Nayeri |first=Farah |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-10-23/sheikha-mayassa-tops-art-power-list-for-1-billion-spend.html |title=Sheikha Mayassa Tops Art Power List for $1 Billion Spend |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2013-10-23 |accessdate=2014-05-13}} Al Mayassa is believed to have been the purchaser of [[Paul Gauguin]]'s ''[[When Will You Marry?]]'' in 2015 for $300 million, [[List of most expensive paintings|a record price for a painting]],{{cite news|last=Reyburn |first=Scott |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/06/arts/design/gauguin-painting-is-said-to-fetch-nearly-300-million.html |title=SGauguin Painting Is Said to Fetch $300 Million |publisher=NY Times |date=2015-02-05 |accessdate=2015-02-09}} [[Cezanne]]'s ''[[The Card Players]]'' in 2012 for $250 million, as well as [[Mark Rothko]]'s ''[[White Center (Yellow, Pink and Lavender on Rose)]]'' in 2007 for $70 million, a [[Damien Hirst]] pill cabinet for $20 million and works by [[Jeff Koons]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Roy Lichtenstein]] and [[Francis Bacon]]. She has staged major exhibitions in Qatar with [[Takashi Murakami]], [[Richard Serra]] and [[Damien Hirst]]. ==Education== Sheikha Al-Mayassa graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] degree in [[Political Science]] and [[Literature]] from [[Duke University]] ([[Durham, North Carolina]], [[United States of America|USA]]) in 2005.{{cite news |title=Mixing Oil and Hollywood: Tribeca Festival Expands to the Persian Gulf |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/24/movies/24tribeca.html |work=[[The New York Times]] | date=23 October 2009 |accessdate=3 November 2010 |first=Larry |last=Rohter}} While at Duke, she was Vice President of the International Association, Vice President of Hiwar (an organization to promote political dialogue),{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} and a delegate to the 2001–2002 [[Model United Nations]]. During the 2003–2004 school year, she studied at the [[University of Paris 1 Pantheon-Sorbonne]], and the [[Institut d'Études Politiques de Paris]] (known as Sciences Po). ==Career== Upon graduation, Sheikha al-Mayassa established the NGO [[Reach Out To Asia]]. This organization is a philanthropic effort inspired by the desire to help the victims of recent natural disasters in Asia by providing quality education; it also celebrated the occasion of the 2006 Asian Games in Doha. Sheikha Al Mayassa is the Chairperson of [[Qatar Museums]], whose CEO Edward Dolman previously served as Chairman of [[Christie's]] International, and responsible for cultivating significant cultural events in the region. She has been profiled extensively in the [[NY Times]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/23/arts/design/qatar-uses-its-riches-to-buy-art-treasures.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 Qatari Riches Are Buying Art World Influence] Sheikha Al Mayassa is also Chairperson of the [[Doha Film Institute]] which partnered with the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] to produce several annual iterations of the [[Doha Tribeca Film Festival]]. In February 2013, they announced a $100 million feature film fund with [[Participant Media]], a production company founded by [[billionaire]] [[Jeffrey Skoll]], who was the first employee and also first president of internet auction firm [[eBay]].{{cite web|date=13 February 2013|website=[[Deadline Hollywood|Deadline]]|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/02/participant-media-doha-film-institute-launch-five-year-100m-feature-film-fund/ |title=Berlin: Participant Media, Doha Film Institute Launch Five-Year $100M Feature Film Fund}} ==Art collecting== Sheikha Al Mayassa's wealth and role as Chairperson of Qatar Museums make her influential among art collectors. [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] reported her acquisition budget on behalf of Qatar Museums is estimated at $1 billion annually.[http://marhaba.qa/whos-who-in-qatar-the-people-of-qatar-you-should-know-about/ marhaba.qa: "Who’s Who in Qatar: The People of Qatar You Should Know About"], 10 Aug 2014 Sheikha Al Mayassa is said to have purchased the most expensive painting in the world, [[Paul Gauguin]]'s [[When Will You Marry?]] in 2015 for $300 million, [[Cezanne]]'s [[The Card Players]] in 2012 for $250 million, as well as [[Mark Rothko]]'s [[White Center (Yellow, Pink and Lavender on Rose)]] in 2007 for $70 million, a [[Damien Hirst]] pill cabinet for $20 million and works by [[Jeff Koons]], [[Andy Warhol]], [[Roy Lichtenstein]] and [[Francis Bacon]]. She has staged major exhibitions in Qatar with [[Takashi Murakami]], [[Richard Serra]] and [[Damien Hirst]] (underwriting his exhibit first at the [[Tate Modern]] prior to opening in Doha). The Sheikha oversees a vast array of museums including the [[I. M. Pei]]-designed [[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]]. A [[Jean Nouvel]]-designed National Museum of Qatar and an Orientalist Museum by [[Herzog & de Meuron]] are slated to open in the coming years. Sheikha Al Mayassa participated in a TED Talk in February 2012, where she highlighted the importance of the social impact of art. She affirmed that her goal was to create a local collection of art to contribute in shaping the Qatari national identity.{{cite web|last1=chronicle.fanack.com|title=Sheikha al-Mayassa, Patron of – Some of – the Arts|url=https://chronicle.fanack.com/qatar/faces/sheikha-al-mayassa-patron-of-some-of-the-arts/|website=fanack.com|accessdate=28 July 2015}} == Family == Sheikha Mayassa is the sister of the [[List of emirs of Qatar|Emir of Qatar]], Sheikh [[Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani]]. Her father Sheikh [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani]] is the former Emir, and mother Sheikha [[Mozah bint Nasser Al-Missned]], the former First Lady. Sheikha Mayassa's mother Sheikha Mozah is responsible for opening campuses of several world-class academic institutions in Doha, including [[Virginia Commonwealth University]], [[Carnegie Mellon University]], [[Georgetown University]], [[Northwestern University]], [[Texas A&M University]] and [[Weill Cornell Medical College]] and the University of Calgary in Qatar. Her brother Sheikh [[Mohammed bin Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]] is the Chairman of Qatar's winning bid to stage the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]] in Doha. Sheikha Al Mayassa's father founded [[Al Jazeera]] and established the [[Qatar Investment Authority]], a sovereign wealth fund to manage the country's oil and natural gas surpluses.17 July 2013 – [[Qatar Investment Authority]] http://www.qia.qa The Qatar Investment Authority and its [[subsidiaries]] have acquired many businesses abroad, including London's iconic department store [[Harrods]] from entrepreneur [[Mohammed Al-Fayed]],8 May 2010 [[Reuters]] – [https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/05/08/us-harrods-idUSTRE6470V520100508 Qatar investor buys UK department store Harrods] [[Paris]] based department store [[Printemps]],8 April 2013 The Wall Street Journal – [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324050304578410763931853602 Qatari Investors to Buy Printemps] French [[football club]] [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.]],24 May 2013 NY Times – [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/25/world/europe/25iht-letter25.html Qatari Hopes for Paris Saint-Germain Meet Reality] a 10% stake in [[Porsche]],17 June 2013 Reuters – [https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/17/us-qatar-porsche-volkswagen-idUSBRE95G08E20130617 Qatar sells back 10 percent Porsche stake to founding families] a 75% stake in [[film studio]] [[Miramax Films|Miramax]] which they acquired from [[Disney]],21 January 2013 [[The Hollywood Reporter]] – [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/ron-tutor-sells-his-miramax-414171 Ron Tutor Sells His Miramax Stake] a 2% stake in [[media conglomerate]] and [[Universal Music Group]] [[parent company]] [[Vivendi]],21 March 2012 [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] -[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-03-21/vivendi-says-shareholder-qatar-holding-raised-its-stake-to-2-.html Vivendi Says Shareholder Qatar Holding Raised its Stake to 2%] a $100 million USD investment in Chernin Group – whose founder [[Peter Chernin]] was COO of [[News Corp]] and President of [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]],8 November 2012 [[LA Times]] – [http://articles.latimes.com/2012/nov/08/entertainment/la-et-ct-chernin-investment-qatar-holdings-20121108 Chernin Group receives $100-million investment from Qatar Holding] a 1% stake in [[luxury goods]] manufacturer [[Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy]],16 March 2012 [[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]] – [http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2012/03/16/qatar-holdings-buys-lvmh-stake Slice Of LVMH] a 6% stake in [[Credit Suisse]],14 February 2011 [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] – [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-14/credit-suisse-places-sf6-billion-in-tier-1-buffer-capital-notes.html Credit Suisse Raises $6.2 Billion From Qatar Holding, Olayan] a 12.6% stake in [[Barclays]]5 February 2013 [[Reuters]] – [https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/05/us-barclays-idUSBRE91408O20130205 Barclays ducks Qatar questions, takes $1.6 billion mis-selling hit] and several other major companies. They also backed [[Glencore]]'s $31 billion USD takeover bid for [[Xstrata]].15 November 2012 [[NY Times]] – [https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/11/15/qatar-holding-supports-glencore-xstrata-deal/ Qatar Wealth Fund Backs Glencore’s Bid for Xstrata] The Qatari sovereign wealth fund is one of the largest property owners in London with their holdings including [[The Shard]], [[Olympic Village, London|Olympic Village]] and [[InterContinental London|Park Lane's InterContinental Hotel]].21 June 2013 [[The Independent]] – [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/sheikh-hamad-bin-jassim-bin-jaber-althani-meet-the-man-who-bought-london-8669134.html Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber al-Thani: Meet the man who bought London] They also own several hotels in [[Cannes]] including the [[Hotel Majestic (Cannes)|Majestic Hotel]], [[Grand Hyatt Cannes Hôtel Martinez]] and [[Carlton Hotel, Cannes|Carlton Hotel]].15 December 2011 [[Pie Magazine|Pie Mag]] – [http://www.pie-mag.com/articles/2360/cannes-carlton-hotel-sold-to-qatar-investor-for-euro-450m/ Cannes Carlton hotel sold to Qatar investor for €450m] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525051640/http://www.pie-mag.com/articles/2360/cannes-carlton-hotel-sold-to-qatar-investor-for-euro-450m |date=25 May 2013 }} QIA was considered to have one of the leading bids in the sales of both [[Anschutz Entertainment Group]]13 November 2012 [[NY Post]] – [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/aeg_shoots_for_stars_with_up_to_lN4j5RKTq7mu7X8S2vRqPM AEG shoots for stars with up to $10B sale] and [[Hulu]].9 June 2013 [[Arabian Business]] – [http://www.arabianbusiness.com/qatar-among-bidders-for-us-online-tv-firm-504486.html Qatar among bidders for US online TV firm] As of May 2013, it was reported the Investment Authority is in talks to purchase [[Neiman Marcus]] and [[Bergdorf Goodman]].31 May 2013 [[NY Post]] – [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/neiman_plays_qatar_Sh8F0MnsFr9LmwdXylsupM Qatar Investment Authority in talks to buy Neiman Marcus] ===Marriage and children=== Sheikha Al-Mayassa married Sheikh Jassim bin Abdul Aziz Al-Thani at Al-Wajbah Palace, Doha, on 6 January 2006. Sheikh Jassim is an elder son of Sheikh Abdul Aziz bin Jassim bin Hamad Al-Thani, making them second cousins. Together they have three sons and one daughter. * Sheikh Mohammed bin Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani. * Sheikh Hamad bin Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani. * Sheikh Abdulaziz bin Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani. * Sheikha Norah bint Jassim bin Abdulaziz Al Thani ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center | boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; | boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; | boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; | boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; | boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; | 1= 1. '''Al-Mayassa bint Hamad Al Thani''' | 2= 2. [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani]] | 3= 3. [[Moza bint Nasser|Moza bint Nasser Al Missned]] | 4= 4. [[Khalifa bin Hamad Al Thani]] | 5= 5. Aisha bint Hamad Al Attiyah | 6= 6. Nasser bin Abdullah Al Missned | 8= 8. [[Hamad bin Abdullah Al Thani]] | 9= 9. a sister of Nasser Al Attiyah | 10= 10. Hamad Al Attiyah | 12= 12. Abdullah bin Ali Al Missned | 16= 16. [[Abdullah bin Jassim Al Thani]] | 17= 17. Mariam bint Abdullah Al Attiyah | 24= 24. Ali Al Missned }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131029204941/http://www.wisemuslimwomen.org/muslimwomen/bio/sheikha_al_mayassa_bint_hamad_bin_khalifa_al-thani/ Muslim Women: Past and Present] about Al-Thani * {{TED speaker|2=Sheikha Al Mayassa}} ** [http://www.ted.com/talks/sheikha_al_mayassa_globalizing_the_local_localizing_the_global "Globalizing the local, localizing the global" (TEDWomen 2010)] {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thani, Al-Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:House of Thani]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:Sciences Po alumni]] [[Category:Qatari people]] [[Category:Qatari art collectors]] [[Category:Museum directors]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Alexander Huie|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
'''Alexander Gordon Huie''' (16 October 1869 – 7 November 1964) was an Australian journalist and [[single tax]] campaigner.
Huie was born at Tayco in the [[Riverina]] to Scottish farmer Alexander Huie and Mary Eliza, ''née'' Carige, who had been born in [[Grenada|British Grenada]]. His family all supported the [[Temperance movement|temperance]] movement. Huie moved to [[Lake Cargelligo]] in 1883 to work as a carpenter, and read [[Henry George]]'s ''[[Progress and Poverty]]'' in 1889. He became a correspondent for the ''Hillston Spectator'' and was appointed secretary of the local progress committee. He contested the seat of [[Electoral district of Lachlan|Lachlan]] in 1894 and would go on to unsuccessfully contest eleven more elections at all levels of government. In 1901 he became founding honorary secretary of the Sydney [[Single Tax League]], although he supported [[Joseph Carruthers]]' [[Liberal Reform Party (Australia)|Liberal and Reform Association]] at the 1904 and 1907 state elections.<ref name=adb>{{Cite web | last = Cunneen | first = Chris | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Huie, Alexander Gordon (1869–1964) | work = [[Australian Dictionary of Biography]] | publisher = [[Australian National University]] | date = 1983 | url = http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/huie-alexander-gordon=6762 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 21 July 2011}}</ref>
Huie founded the single tax journal the ''Standard'' in December 1905, remaining editor and secretary of the Single Tax League until December 1953. He had about 220 letters published in the ''[[Sydney Morning Herald]]'' between 1916 and 1962, and was a strong supporter of [[proportional representation]]. He married Annie Bertha Lark, ''née'' Bartlett, a [[Malta|Maltese]]-born widow, on 1 October 1921 in a [[Methodist]] ceremony at [[Ashfield, New South Wales|Ashfield]], where they settled; Annie would predecease him in 1948. He regularly spoke in the [[The Domain, Sydney|Sydney Domain]]. Huie died in 1964 visiting Lake Cargelligo, where he is buried with [[Presbyterian]] forms.<ref name=adb/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Huie, Alexander}} [[Category:1869 births]] [[Category:1964 deaths]] [[Category:Georgists]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Alistair Lawrence | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | nationality = | field = [[Ethology]] | prizes = [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|RSPCA]]/[[British Society of Animal Science|BSAS]] award {{small|(1995)}}.<ref name="bsas">{{cite web |url=http://bsas.org.uk/about-bsas/funds-awards-jobs/rspcabsas-award-for-innovative-developments-in-animal-welfare/rspca-bsas-awards |title=RSPCA BSAS Awards |publisher=[[British Society of Animal Science]] |date=2016 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> }} Professor '''Alistair B. Lawrence''' (born 1954) is an [[ethology|ethologist]].<ref name="isae">{{cite web |url=http://www.isae2016.co.uk/index.php/congress/15-congress-organisers |title=Alistair Lawrence |publisher=[[International Society for Applied Ethology]] |date=2016 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> He currently holds a joint chair in animal behaviour and welfare at [[Scotland's Rural College]] and the [[University of Edinburgh]].<ref name="oie">{{cite web |url=http://animal-welfare.oie.int/cv_lawrence.htm |title=Alistair Lawrence |publisher=[[World Organisation for Animal Health]] |date=2004 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref>
==Education== Lawrence graduated from the [[University of St Andrews]] with a degree in zoology.<ref name="oie" /> He then studied for his PhD at the University of Edinburgh under the direction of [[D. G. M. Wood-Gush|David Wood-Gush]].<ref name="oie" />
==Career== In 1995 he received the [[Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals|RSPCA]]/[[British Society of Animal Science|BSAS]] award for innovative developments in animal welfare for his 'outstanding contribution to animal welfare research'.<ref name="bsas">{{cite web |url=http://bsas.org.uk/about-bsas/funds-awards-jobs/rspcabsas-award-for-innovative-developments-in-animal-welfare/rspca-bsas-awards |title=RSPCA BSAS Awards |publisher=[[British Society of Animal Science]] |date=2016 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref>
He has published extensively throughout his career.{{Google Scholar id|76yDQfQAAAAJ&hl|Alistair Lawrence}}<ref name="microsoft">{{AcademicSearch|2628464801}}</ref>
Lawrence is a past secretary of the [[International Society for Applied Ethology]] and is a supporter of [[Compassion in World Farming]].<ref name="isae" /><ref name="ciwf">{{cite web |url=http://www.ciwf.org.uk/about-us/high-profile-supporters/visionaries/academia/professor-alistair-lawrence/ |title=Professor Alistair Lawrence |publisher=[[Compassion in World Farming]] |date=2016 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> He has served on the UK [[Farm Animal Welfare Committee]] and has been appointed to the council of the [[Universities Federation for Animal Welfare]].<ref name="ciwf" />
With [[Aubrey Manning]] he oversees the David Wood-Gush Trust Fund that set up and supports the annual Wood-Gush lecture.<ref name="isae" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.sruc.ac.uk/alawrence Scotland's Rural College homepage] *[https://www.ed.ac.uk/roslin/about/contact-us/staff/alistair-lawrence University of Edinburgh homepage] *{{IMDb name|2456020|Alistair Lawrence}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lawrence, Alistair}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ethologists]] [[Category:People educated at Strathallan School]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of St Andrews]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Animal welfare scholars]] [[Category:20th-century scientists]] [[Category:21st-century scientists]] [[Category:People from Perthshire]]

revision.text: {{About|the YouTube personality|the basketball player|Andrew Hayles}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use American English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Andrew Hales | image = | caption = | birth_name = Andrew Gerald Hales | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1990|05|20}} | birth_place = [[Ithaca, New York]] | home_town = [[Ithaca, New York]] | residence = [[Los Angeles]] | years_active = 2009–present | height = 6 ft 2 in | nationality = [[United States|American]] | occupation = YouTube personality | education = {{unbulleted list|[[Utah Valley University]]|[[Brookfield High School (Connecticut)|Brookfield High School]] (class of 2008)}} | website = {{URL|https://lahwf.me/}} | relatives = [[Jaclyn Hales]] (Sister) | module = {{Infobox YouTube personality|embed=yes | channels = [https://www.youtube.com/user/LAHWF LAHWF], [https://www.youtube.com/user/LAHWFextra LAHWFextra] | genre = [[Practical joke|Prank]]s, [[Video log|vlog]]s | network = | associated_acts = {{flatlist| * [[Stuart Edge]] }} }} }} '''Andrew Gerald Hales''', known as '''Andrew Hales''' is an American [[YouTube personality]] and [[vlogger]] known for his channel '''LAHWF''', which has videos consisting of [[Practical joke|pranks]] and interviews. == Early life == Hales was born on May 20, 1990 in [[Ithaca, New York]] in a [[Mormon]] family but no longer practices the religion. His father, as a pharmaceutical salesman, moved their family from [[New York (state)|New York]] to [[New Hampshire]] and then to [[Bountiful, Utah|Bountiful]]. Although he grew up in multiple places, he calls [[Utah]] his home state. He also lived in [[Brookfield, Connecticut]] for a large part of his life and graduated [[Brookfield High School (Connecticut)|Brookfield High School]] class of 2008 prior to attending Utah Valley University. He attended [[Utah Valley University]] for 3 years. == YouTube == Hales started filming videos for his channel at [[Utah Valley University|UVU]], but had to leave and go to other places such as [[Brigham Young University|BYU]] because people started to recognize him. He has filmed videos around the globe as well as places around the United States, such as [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Los Angeles]], [[Colorado]], [[Idaho]], [[Miami]], [[London]], [[Rome]], [[Amsterdam]], and [[Chengdu]] in [[China]]. He paid for school using money earned from his videos. === LAHWF === LAHWF, the name of Hales's YouTube channel, stands for "losing all hope was freedom," a quote from the 1999 film [[Fight Club]]. === "Holding People's Hand" === Hales as a part of [[UVU]] students filmed a video where he went to random people who are walking by and tried to awkwardly hold their hands, this original prank idea was released on June 11, 2012 and went [[viral video|viral]]. The second part of this video which Hales was on a family vacation, filmed in [[Lake George, New York]] featuring his sister [[Jaclyn Hales|Jaclyn]] and was released on July 22, 2012. === Macklemore Look-alike === On October 28, 2013, Hales released a video which was recorded during [[Macklemore & Ryan Lewis]]'s tour stop at Utah's [[Maverik Center]] where he wears a [[hoodie]] and sunglasses and pretends to be [[Macklemore]] and starts pranking people. Later on, Macklemore reacted to this prank on [[Twitter]]. === "Acting Out The Notebook with Girls" === In February 2015, Hales released a video recorded at the [[University of Southern California|USC]], in which he acted out the famous kissing scene from [[the Notebook]] with random participants. The girl who first showed up in the video, later appeared in the extras from his 2016 video, "What are you guys talking about?" in which he returned to USC. === "DumbPranksTV" === In an episode of Hales channel, he posts [[parody]] of staged/fake prank videos under the title of "DumbPranksTV" where the other YouTube personalities may or may not use hired actors/actresses to create a [[viral video]]. == Adderall == Hales has talked about how he was diagnosed with [[Attention deficit disorder|A.D.D.]] many times and released a documentary video about [[Adderall]] on August 8, 2016. He mentioned he was prescribed Adderall about 6 months before he started his channel and said he has never seen the doctor who diagnosed him with ADD again. He also said that Adderall is the reason behind all his videos, but mentioned he doesn't want to talk about the subject because he doesn't take treatment any more. == References == {{Reflist|2|refs= {{cite web |author=Kelsey Drapkin |url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/2013/07/30/meet-the-23-year-old-that-only-has-to-work-4-hours-a-week-because-his-awkward-videos-are-such-a-hit/ |title=Meet the 23-Year-Old Who Only Has to Work 4 Hours a Week Because His Awkward Videos Are Such a Hit |publisher=[[TheBlaze]] |date=July 30, 2013 |accessdate=August 14, 2016}} {{cite web |author= Jimmy Hall |url=http://www.uvureview.com/recent/uvu-lifestyle/andrew-hales-experimenting-awkward/ |title=Andrew Hales, experimenting with awkward |publisher=[[UVU Review]]|date=March 24, 2014|accessdate=August 15, 2016}} {{cite web |author=Carlie Ellett |url=http://universe.byu.edu/2013/02/12/youtube-channel-has-fans-lahwf-ing/ |title=YouTube channel has fans "LAHWF-ing" |publisher=[[The Universe (student newspaper)|The Daily Universe]] |date=February 12, 2013 |accessdate=August 14, 2016}} {{cite interview | interviewer = Meredith Forrest Kulwicki and Allison Croghan |title = Meet the Utahn behind viral videos | location= Utah | date= August 14, 2012 | accessdate= August 16, 2016 | url = http://fox13now.com/2012/08/14/meet-the-utahn-behind-viral-videos/ | publisher = [[KSTU]]}} {{cite web |author=Sean P. Means |url=http://archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/sltrib/entertainment2/55033458-223/com-county-king-onlinetoday.html.csp|title=Utah County videomakers spark a viral explosion |publisher= [[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=August 12, 2012|accessdate=August 16, 2016}} {{cite web |author=|url=http://www.missinfo.tv/index.php/a-man-successfully-pretends-to-be-macklemore/|title=A Man Successfully Pretends to be Macklemore |publisher= [[Miss Info]]|date=October 28, 2013|accessdate=August 16, 2016}} {{cite web |author=Macklemore|url=https://twitter.com/macklemore/status/395104520771866624|title=This dude gets free VIP for life |publisher= |date=October 29, 2013|accessdate=August 16, 2016}} {{cite web |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/holding-hands-with-strangers-prank-goes-viral-almost-2-million-hits-in-3-days-video-76645/| title='Holding Hands With Strangers' Prank Goes Viral, Almost 2 Million Hits in 3 Days (VIDEO)|date=June 14, 2012| publisher=[[The Christian Post]]|accessdate=September 28, 2016 | author = Daniel Distant}} {{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/holding-hands-strangers-prank-uvu-college-student-andrew-hales-goes-viral-youtube-video-702588| title=?Holding Hands With Strangers? Prank By UVU College Student Andrew Hales Goes Viral On YouTube [VIDEO]|date=June 13, 2012| publisher=[[International Business Times]]|accessdate=September 28, 2016|author=Nadine DeNinno}} }} == External links == * {{Official website|https://lahwf.me/}} * {{IMDb name|6008792}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hales, Andrew}} [[Category:1990 births]] [[Category:Pranksters]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Ithaca, New York]] [[Category:American YouTubers]] [[Category:People from Los Angeles]] [[Category:People from Bountiful, Utah]] [[Category:Video bloggers]]

{{Infobox Officeholder | name=António Ng
{{small|''Ng Kuok Cheong''}} | native_name = {{nobold|吳國昌}} | native_name_lang = zh-mo | image = 20071220NgKuokCheong.jpg | caption= Antonio Ng at the December 20, 2007 demonstration | office=Member of the [[Legislative Assembly of Macau|Legislative Assembly]] | constituency=[[Geographical constituency (Macau)|Macau (Directly elected)]] | term_start=30 September 1992 | term_end= | nationality=Portuguese, Macau Chinese | birth_date={{birth date and age|1957|9|26}} | birth_place=[[Nanhai District|Nanhai]], [[Guangdong]], [[China]] | death_date= | death_place= | spouse= | party=[[New Democratic Macau Association]] | religion=[[Roman Catholic]] }} '''António Ng Kuok Cheong''' ({{zh|t=吳國昌|s=吴国昌|p=Wú Guóchāng}}; born September 26, 1957 in [[Nanhai District|Nanhai]], [[Guangdong]]; moved to [[Macau]] in 1959) is currently a member in the [[Legislative Assembly of Macau|Macau Legislative Assembly]], returned by direct election. He was the founding chairman of the pro-democratic political party [[New Macau Association]]. He is also the leader of the political pressure group [[Union for Democracy Development]]. Ng has been a major figure in the Macau democracy movement and is one of the three pro-democratic legislators in the Assembly. After his graduation from [[Yuet Wah College]], Macau, Ng obtained his undergraduate degree in economics at [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]]. ==Election results== {| class="wikitable" revision.text:
[[File:Portrait of Baron du Potet.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Baron du Potet; frontispiece of ''La magie dévoilée et la science occulte'', 1852 edition.]]
'''Jules Denis, Baron du Potet''' or '''Dupotet de Sennevoy''' (12 April 1796 – 1 July 1881) was a French [[esotericist]]. He practiced homeopathy in London during part of his life, and became a renowned practitioner of mesmerism—the theories first developed by [[Franz Mesmer]] involving [[animal magnetism]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sollier|first=Paul|year=1903|title=L'autoscopie interne|journal=[[Revue philosophique de la France et de l'étranger]]|volume=55|pages=1–41|jstor=41077720}}</ref>
==Life== He was born at [[Sennevoy-le-Haut]], the son of Charles Jean-Baptiste Dupotet, seigneur de La Chapelle et de Sennevoy, and Pierrette Babeau Simone. He was married twice, to Aglaé Saunier in Paris in 1833, and the second time to Marie Isaure Hérault. He died in Paris and is buried in the [[Montmartre Cemetery]].<ref>C.A.P. 291 (1843), Allée Samson, Division 23, Row 3, 15th tomb from the left; gravestone broken.</ref>
==Career== Du Potet was a highly successful mesmerist. Some attributed this to the fact he was missing the thumb on his right hand.<ref name=Clarke>{{cite book |last=Clarke |first=James Fernandez |title=Autobiographical Recollections of the Medical Profession |location=London |publisher=Churchill |year=1874 |oclc=559634098 |url=https://archive.org/stream/autobiographica01clargoog#page/n180/mode/2up |page=161 }}</ref> His reputation was such, apparently, that a man was convicted of murder and executed based on evidence given by "one of Du Potet's clairvoyantes".<ref name=blackmagic>{{cite journal |year=1890 |title=Black Magic in Science |journal=[[Lucifer (magazine)|Lucifer]] |volume=6 |issue=34 |pages=265–75 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_jgbAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA272}}</ref> He operated a free school of magnetism in Paris from 1826 on,<ref name=Deveney>{{cite book |last=Deveney |first=John Patrick |title=Paschal Beverly Randolph: A Nineteenth-Century Black American Spiritualist, Rosicrucian, and Sex Magician |series=SUNY series in Western esoteric traditions |location=Albany, New York |publisher=State University of New York |year=1997 |isbn=9780585042800 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qhs9obpHqhIC&pg=PA53&lpg=PA53&dq=Jules+Dupotet+Denis&source=bl&ots=LSZu3BsvzA&sig=3Loraq3bkFZC8oqRCZHaraGSDU4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HVKzU4raKIvooAShtoCYDQ&ved=0CEwQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Jules%20Dupotet%20Denis&f=false |pages=53–55 }}</ref> and from 1837 to 1845 practised as a homeopathic physician in London,<ref name=Goodrick>{{cite book |last=Goodrick-Clarke |first=Nicholas |authorlink=Nicholas Goodrick-Clarke |title=The Western Esoteric Traditions: A Historical Introduction |location=Oxford/New York |publisher=Oxford University |year=2008 |isbn=9780195320992 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IPwoK5XYXrAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Goodrick+Clarke,+The+Western+Esoteric+Traditions&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QWSzU5L9M4L6oATB44KoDg&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Dupotet&f=false |page=183 }}</ref> where he successfully treated [[Epilepsy|epileptic]] girls at the [[North London Hospital]]<ref name=Clarke/> and according to a letter to the editor of ''[[The Lancet]]'' his experiments became the talk of the town.<ref>{{cite journal|year=1837|title=Animal Magnetism|journal=[[The American Journal of the Medical Sciences]]|pages=507–509|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AVk9AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA507}}</ref>
For du Potet, who was in correspondence with [[Magnetizer|mesmerists]] worldwide, mesmerism was, not unlike [[Utopian socialism]], an aid in bringing about social transformation, even a revolution.<ref name="Bell">{{cite book|last=Bell|first=Caryn Cossé|title=Revolution, Romanticism, and the Afro-Creole Protest Tradition in Louisiana, 1718—1868|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0wwK-IQ4UZIC&pg=PT177|date=1997-02-01|publisher=LSU Press|isbn=9780807153451|pages=177–79}}</ref> An 1890 article in the English occult magazine ''[[Lucifer (magazine)|Lucifer]]'' praises him as an ardent supporter of mesmerism whose "powerful voice" might have stopped the "travesty" of hypnotism.<ref name=blackmagic/>
Du Potet also pursued occult applications of mesmerism. [[Eliphas Levi]] praised him highly in his ''History of Magic'', and said that magnetism had unlocked for him the secrets of magic.<ref>{{cite book|last=Levi|first=Eliphas |title=The History of Magic |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DIVo4hmp6ooC&pg=PA339|year=1999 |publisher=Weiser |isbn=9780877289296 |pages=339–40}}</ref> Unlike Levi, he believed that trance enabled contact with the dead and with never incarnated spirits, and his circle believed in [[Psychokinesis|remote influence]] by means of magnetic currents.<ref name=Deveney/> He was a member of the [[Theosophical Society]]; his writings were quoted extensively by [[Helena Blavatsky]], who regarded him as an adept.<ref name=Goodrick/> In ''[[The Discovery of the Unconscious]]'', [[Henri Ellenberger]] considers him to have "developed ... delusions of grandeur".<ref>{{cite book |last=Ellenburger |first=Henri F. |authorlink=Henri Ellenberger |title=The Discovery of the Unconscious: The History and Evolution of Dynamic Psychiatry |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ke1jd_e7AyYC&pg=PA906&dq=Jules+Dupotet+Denis&hl=en&sa=X&ei=6WezU7C8FsXdoAT-6IBg&ved=0CBsQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=incarnation%20of%20magnetism&f=false |location=New York |publisher=Basic Books |year=1970 |page=156 }}</ref>
Du Potet published and edited the ''Journal du magnetisme''<ref name="Matlock"/> from 1845 to 1861. Books he wrote include ''Introduction to the Study of Animal Magnetism'' (1838) and ''La magie dévoilée et la science occulte'' (1852), a copy of which was owned by [[Victor Hugo]].<ref name="Matlock">{{cite journal|last=Matlock|first=Jann|year=2000|title=Ghostly Politics|journal=[[Diacritics (journal)|Diacritics]]|volume=30|issue=3|pages=53–71|jstor=1566343}}</ref>
== Footnotes == {{Reflist}}
== References == * Gauld, A., ''A History of Hypnotism'', Cambridge University Press, 1992. * [https://archive.org/details/b24872210_0002 Harte, R., ''Hypnotism and the Doctors, Volume I: Animal Magnetism: Mesmer/De Puysegur'', L.N. Fowler & Co., (London), 1902]. * [https://archive.org/details/hypnotismanddoc00hartgoog Harte, R., ''Hypnotism and the Doctors, Volume II: The Second Commission; Dupotet And Lafontaine; The English School; Braid's Hypnotism; Statuvolism; Pathetism; Electro-Biology'', L.N. Fowler & Co., (London), 1903].
==External links== *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k123162m.r=Magie.langFR ''La magie dévoilée et la science occulte'', 1852 edition] at [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Potet, Baron du}} [[Category:1796 births]] [[Category:1881 deaths]] [[Category:Esotericists]] [[Category:French homeopaths]] [[Category:People from Yonne]]

{{more footnotes|BLP=yes|date=February 2014}} '''Bassem Youssef''' (born [[Egypt]]) is a senior American FBI agent. He was the highest ranking American agent of Coptic descent employed by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] as of 2009, as a Unit Chief in the FBI’s [[Counterterrorism]] Division. Prior to holding this position, Youssef coordinated the national counterterrorism investigation into the Islamic Group, the organization responsible for the first [[World Trade Center (1973-2001)|World Trade Center]] bombing.
==Career== Youssef was born in Egypt in a Coptic Christian family.<ref>FBI whistleblowers: hearing before the Subcommittee United States. Congress. House. Committee on the Judiciary. Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, and Homeland Security - 2009 "Bassem Youssef Bassem Youssef is the FBI's highest-ranking Arab American agent. ... His background as an Egyptian-born Coptic Christian and native Arabic speaker should have made him one of the FBI's most valued and appreciated ..."</ref> He speaks fluent Arabic (the highest ranking FBI official with this skill).
In 1994, he earned the Intelligence Community’s prestigious and coveted award, the [[National Intelligence Distinguished Service Medal]], awarded by the Director of Central Intelligence (DCI). The award was for outstanding accomplishments in a terrorism case involving an al-Qaeda-related investigation.
After obtaining the DCI award, he was selected by the former FBI Director [[Louis Freeh]] to head of the FBI’s overseas office with responsibility for Saudi Arabia and the contiguous Gulf States, including UAE, Kuwait, Oman, Yemen, Bahrain and Qatar. The FBI’s internal inspection of that office, conducted in 2000, highly praised Youssef’s performance. Inspection reports are kept confidential within the FBI, and are tasked with identifying problems in various programs.
According to an FBI report drafted in 2000, within three months of his arrival in Saudi Arabia Youssef's "efforts led to the establishment of direct communications with senior officials of the Mabahith [Saudi Arabia's security service] which had previously been unavailable to US Embassy personnel." These contacts were crucial in establishing a first-ever meeting between then-FBI director Louis Freeh and Saudi officials.
==Whistleblower== In July, 2006 the Justice Department's [[Office of Professional Responsibility]] concluded that the FBI illegally retaliated against Youssef because he had allegedly made whistleblower disclosures to the Director of the FBI and a [[Member of Congress]].<ref> United States of America Congressional Record - Page 6365 "Consider the case of FBI Special Agent Bassem Youssef. According to a Washington Post article from July 18, 2006, an internal investigation conducted by the United States Justice Department concluded that Youssef, the FBI's highest"</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ala.org/ala/alonline/currentnews/newsarchive/2008/january2008/bassemyoussef.cfm ''FBI Whistleblower Answers Questions in Philadelphia''] * [http://whistleblowers.org/html/inside_the_fbi.html ''Bassem Youssef's Information at the National Whistleblower Center''] * [http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16042604/ ''NBC Nightly news''] * https://www.npr.org/about/press/archives.html * http://abcnews.go.com/TheLaw/DOJ/story?id=4905061&page=1 * https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2008-01-12-fbi-whistleblower_N.htm * https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/11/AR2008011103665.html
{{DEFAULTSORT:Youssef, Bassem}} [[Category:American people of Coptic descent]] [[Category:American people of Egyptian descent]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]] [[Category:FBI agents]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:People from Cairo]] [[Category:Recipients of the National Intelligence Distinguished Service Medal]]

revision.text:
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox sportsperson| | name = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | fullname = | sport = Soccer / Cerebral palsy soccer | nicknames = | nationality = {{USA}} | club = | collegeteam = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1990|8|29}} | birth_place = | paralympics = [[2012 Summer Paralympics]] | height = {{height|m=1.8288}} | weight = {{convert|160|lb|kg|abbr=on}} | medaltemplates= {{MedalSport | Paralympic 7-a-side football}} {{MedalCompetition|2010 Americas Championship}} {{MedalSilver | Team | Men's }} {{MedalCompetition|[[America's Cup]]}} {{MedalBronze | 2014 | Men's }} | updated = 18 June 2016 }}
'''Bryce Boarman''' (born August 29, 1990) is an American Paralympic soccer player. Boarman has cerebral palsy, and attended the [[University of Colorado Colorado Springs]] and [[University of Northern Colorado]].
Boarman took up soccer when he was 6 years old. Boarman got involved with Paralympic soccer in 2008, but missed out on the Paralympic Games because the US failed to qualify. He then went on to represent the US at the 2009 CPISRA World Championships, 2011 CPISRA World Championships, the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]], the 2015 CPISRA World Championships and the 2015 Parapan American Games. He has over 60 caps for the US national team.
== Personal == Boarman is from Colorado Springs, Colorado.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2016/03/03/16/08/160303-pnt-paralympic-team-heads-to-chula-vista-for-training-camp|title=U.S. PARALYMPIC TEAM HEADS TO CHULA VISTA FOR TRAINING CAMP|last=|first=|date=March 3, 2016|website=U.S. Soccer|publisher=U.S. Soccer|access-date=May 15, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.denverpost.com/olympics/2012/08/25/colorado-boasting-athletes-london-2012-paralympics/23380/|title=Colorado boasting 2nd most U.S. athletes at London 2012 Paralympics|last=Dumlao|first=Ros|date=August 25, 2012|work=Denver Post|access-date=May 18, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://gazette.com/ex-soldier-gives-up-competition-for-coaching/article/41439|title=Ex-soldier gives up competition for coaching|last=Gomez|first=Brian|date=October 4, 2008|work=The Gazette|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref> When he was a baby, he was diagnosed as having [[cerebral palsy]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.uccs.edu/business/academics/bachelors-degrees/sport-management/paralympian-bryce-boarman.html|title=UCCS commencement a milestone for Paralympian|last=Hutton|first=Tom|date=December 18, 2013|website=|publisher=University of Colorado Colorado Springs|access-date=June 18, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://issuu.com/thescribeuccs/docs/92410|title=Bryce Boarman represents U.S. at 2012 London Paralympics|last=Hernandez|first=Kailey|date=September 24, 2012|website=|publisher=The Scribe|pages=18|access-date=June 18, 2012}}</ref> He graduated from [[University of Colorado Colorado Springs]] in December 2013 with a degree in sports management.<ref name=":4" /> He then enrolled at [[University of Northern Colorado]] to pursue a graduate degree.<ref name=":4" />
Boarman started playing soccer when he was 6 years old.<ref name=":4" />
== Cerebral palsy football == Boarman is a CP5 classified footballer,<ref name=rostersalou/> serving as a defender when playing for the national team.<ref name=":0" /> Boarman has over 60 caps for the USPNT.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=http://www.teamusa.org/para-soccer/athletes/Bryce-Boarman|title=Bryce Boarman|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Team USA|publisher=US Olympic Committee|access-date=June 18, 2016}}</ref>
When Paralympic sportspeople in the United States first recognized his talent, they tried to recruit him for athletics. After he expressed more interest in soccer, they put him in touch with the USPNT who then went on to invite him to a national team training tryout.<ref name=":6" /> After the 2008, Boarman was a selected to the USPNT later that year. The team was unable to qualify for the Beijing 2008 Paralympic Games.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":6" /> He went on to attend the Beijing Games as a spectator.<ref name=":7" /> He participated in a training camp in October 2008 in California.<ref name=":3" />
In 2009, Boarman was again with the USPNT, this time for the 2011 CPISRA World Championships where the United States finished eleventh.<ref name=":7" /> The following year, he was part of the silver medal winning US side at the 2010 Americas Championship.<ref name=":7" />
Boarman was a member of the US team that participated in the 2011 CPISRA World Championships.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eastcountymagazine.org/la-mesa-athlete-goes-dutch-play-japan-june-19th|title=LA Mesa Athlete Goes Dutch to Play Japan on June 19th|last=Logan|first=Ron|date=June 2011|work=East County Magazine|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://lacancha.net/2012/08/31/u-s-paralympic-national-team-paralympic-games-riverbank-arena-london-england-sept-1-9-2012/|title=U.S. Paralympic National Team – Paralympic Games Riverbank Arena; London, England Sept. 1-9, 2012|last=Robbins|first=Gerard|date=August 31, 2012|work=La Cancha|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref> They finished eighth.<ref name=":7" /> In 2012, he was one of three members of the USPNT to be get funding assistance from the [[Challenged Athletes Foundation|Challenged Athlete Foundation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.challengedathletes.org/site/c.4nJHJQPqEiKUE/b.8326607/k.9E/2012_CAF_Paralympians.htm|title=2012 CAF Paralympians|last=|first=|date=2012|website=|publisher=Challenged Athlete Foundation|access-date=June 18, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006153516/http://www.challengedathletes.org/site/c.4nJHJQPqEiKUE/b.8326607/k.9E/2012_CAF_Paralympians.htm|archivedate=October 6, 2014|df=}}</ref> He was with the United States team at the 2012 Summer Paralympics.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timescall.com/opinion/letterstotheeditor/ci_21534258/newstip|title=Catherine Stokley: No Paralympics coverage?|last=Stokley|first=Catherine|date=September 13, 2012|work=Times-Call|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thestarnews.com/sports/let-the-games-begin-london-calls-to-chula-vista-olympic-training-center-athletes/|title=Let the Games begin! London calls to Chula Vista Olympic Training Center athletes|last=Brents|first=Phillip|date=July 27, 2012|work=The Star-News|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.blazesports.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/London_2012_Paralympic_Games_Media_Guide1.pdf|title=Team USA Media Guide|last=|first=|date=2012|website=Blaze Sports|publisher=United States Olympic Committee|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theoriginalwinger.com/2012/08/video-u-s-paralympic-soccer-team-ready-for-london-games/|title=Video :: U.S. Paralympic Soccer Team Ready For London Games|last=Dunny|first=|date=August 28, 2012|work=The Original Winger|access-date=June 18, 2016|via=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923153442/http://theoriginalwinger.com/2012/08/video-u-s-paralympic-soccer-team-ready-for-london-games/|archivedate=September 23, 2016|df=}}</ref> On the day of the opening ceremonies in London, Boarman celebrated his 22nd birthday.<ref name=":4" /> The United States was drawn in Group B with Ukraine, Great Britain and Brazil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2014/03/17/13/09/us-paralympic-national-team-head-coach-jay-hoffman-selects-roster-for-paralympic-games|title=U.S. PARALYMPIC NATIONAL TEAM HEAD COACH JAY HOFFMAN SELECTS 12-PLAYER ROSTER FOR 2012 PARALYMPIC GAMES|last=|first=|date=July 26, 2016|work=US Soccer|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref> Their opener was against reigning Paralympic gold medal winners Ukraine.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2014/03/17/11/34/us-paralympic-national-team-faces-ukraine-in-2012-london-paralympics-opener|title=U.S. PARALYMPIC NATIONAL TEAM FACES UKRAINE IN 2012 LONDON PARALYMPICS OPENER|last=|first=|date=August 30, 2012|website=|publisher=U.S. Soccer|access-date=June 18, 2016}}</ref> They lost to Great Britain 0 - 4 during group play.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://paralympics.org.uk/news/seven-a-siders-slot-four-past-usa-for-first-games-points|title=Seven-a-siders slot four past USA for first Games points|last=|first=|date=September 5, 2012|work=ParalympicsGB|access-date=June 18, 2016|via=}}</ref> Two generations of his family traveled to London to watch him play.<ref name=":4" />
Boarman was one of four defenders who participated in a national team training camp in March 2013 at the U.S. Olympic Training Center in Chula Vista, California.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.southernsoccerscene.com/2013/03/15/paralympic-soccer-roster-2/|title=Paralympic Soccer Roster|last=Southern Soccer Scene|first=|date=March 15, 2013|work=Southern Soccer Scene|access-date=June 18, 2016|via=}}</ref> For the 2013 Intercontinental Cup, Boarman was again part of the US squad. His team finished eighth.<ref name=":7" />
In April 2014, he was invited to participate in a week long national team training camp at the Olympic Training Center in Chula Vista, California. The camp was being held in preparation for the 7-a-side Football Ciutat de Barcelona in June of that year.<ref name="barcacamp">{{Cite news|url=http://www.socceramerica.com/article/57604/us-paralympic-national-team-roster.html|title=U.S. Paralympic national team roster|last=|first=|date=April 22, 2014|work=Soccer America Daily|access-date=May 15, 2016|via=}}</ref> In 2014, he was part of the US squad that won a bronze medal at the 2014 Americas Cup.<ref name=":7" /> In March 2015, he was part of the 14 man roster that participated in the Povoa de Varzim, Portugal hosted Footie 7 – Povoa 2015 tournament.<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://rushsoccer.com/en/86-front-page-stories/301-keith-johnson-us-paralympic-national-team|title=KEITH JOHNSON – US PARALYMPIC NATIONAL TEAM|last=|first=|date=September 1, 2015|website=Rush Soccer|publisher=|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref> The competition was a warmup for the World Championships that were held in England in June 2015.<ref name=":02" /> He was invited to a national team training camp that took place from April 29 to May 6, 2015 in Carson, California. This camp was in preparation for the 2015 Cerebral Palsy Football World Championships in June of that year in England.<ref name="carsoncamp">{{Cite news|url=http://www.socceramerica.com/article/63483/us-paralympic-team-prepping-for-world-championsh.html|title=U.S. Paralympic team prepping for world championship|last=Woitalla|first=Mike|date=April 27, 2015|work=Soccer America Daily|access-date=May 15, 2016|via=}}</ref>
Participating at the 2015 World Championships, Boarman scored a goal in the US's game 3-0 victory against Venezuela.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1028084/brazil-thrash-scotland-to-begin-cerebral-palsy-football-world-championships-campaign-in-style|title=Brazil thrash Scotland to begin Cerebral Palsy Football World Championships campaign in style|last=Morgan|first=Liam|date=|work=InsideTheGames|access-date=May 17, 2016|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/disability/2015/jun/cp-world-championships-roundup-day-2|title=CP roundup: Wins for USA, Brazil, Canada and Netherlands|last=Reid|first=Jamie|date=June 17, 2015|website=The FA|publisher=|access-date=June 18, 2016}}</ref> He was a starter in the team's 10 - 0 loss to England.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/disability/2015/jun/england-v-usa-match-report-200615|title=England booked an intriguing final Cerebral Palsy World Championships fixture against the Republic of Ireland, after a commanding 10-0 victory against USA.|last=Reid|first=Jamie|date=June 26, 2015|website=The FA|publisher=|access-date=May 21, 2016}}</ref> He came in as a sub in the USA's 2 - 1 win against Scotland.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soccerwire.com/news/nt/international-men/u-s-paralympic-national-team-completes-comeback-for-2-1-win-over-scotland/|title=U.S. Paralympic National Team completes comeback for 2-1 win over Scotland|last=U.S. Soccer|first=|date=June 20, 2015|work=Soccer Wire|access-date=May 21, 2016|via=}}</ref>
Boarman was part of the 14 man squad that represented the United States at the 2015 Parapan American Games in Toronto. There, the United States played Canada, Venezuela, Argentina and Brazil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soccernation.com/uspnt-roster-for-the-2015-parapan-american-games/|title=USPNT ROSTER FOR THE 2015 PARAPAN AMERICAN GAMES|last=|first=|date=August 6, 2015|work=Soccer Nation|access-date=May 15, 2016|via=}}</ref> He took part in a national team training camp in Chula Vista, California in early March 2016.<ref name=":0" /> He was part of the USPNT that took part in the 2016 Pre Paralympic Tournament in [[Salou]], [[Spain]].<ref name="rostersalou">{{Cite web|url=http://media.wix.com/ugd/ec86d3_605daf1002c543fbb466a4d9298f8bf5.pdf|title=United States — Roster|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref> The United States finished 6th after beating Argentina in one placement match 4 - 3 and losing to Ireland 4 - 1. The goals scored in the match against Argentina were the first the USA scored in the tournament, before putting up one more in their match against Ireland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/match/171|title=Ireland — USA|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/match/170|title=USA — Argentina|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/match/169|title=Argentina — Ireland|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref> The tournament featured 7 of the 8 teams participating in Rio. It was the last major preparation event ahead of the Rio Games for all teams participating.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ifcpf.com/tournaments/international-tournament-schedule|title=Schedule|last=|first=|website=IFCPF|publisher=IFCPF|access-date=15 May 2016}}</ref>

'''Carol Hanisch''' is a [[radical feminist]] and was an important member of [[New York Radical Women]] and [[Redstockings]]. She is best known for popularizing the phrase ''[[the personal is political]]'' in a 1969 essay of the same name.<ref name="Smith2012">{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Dale M.|title=Poets Beyond the Barricade: Rhetoric, Citizenship, and Dissent after 1960|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yUNq2Ni019wC&pg=PA153|accessdate=1 August 2012|date=2012-01-15|publisher=University of Alabama Press|isbn=9780817317492|pages=153–}}</ref> She also conceived the 1968 [[Miss America protest]] and was one of the four women who hung a women's liberation banner over the balcony at the [[Miss America Pageant]], disrupting the proceedings.<ref name="Buchanan2011">{{cite book|last=Buchanan|first=Paul D.|title=Radical Feminists: A Guide to an American Subculture|url=|date=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781598843576|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=lx5TlteHLvAC&pg=PA124 124ff]}}</ref>
==Early life== Hanisch was born and raised in Iowa, and worked as a wire services reporter in Des Moines before leaving to join the [[Delta Ministry]] in Mississippi in 1965, inspired by the [[Freedom Summer]] reports the year before. There, she met the co-founders of the Southern Conference Education Fund (SCEF), [[Anne Braden]] and husband [[Carl Braden]], who hired her to run the SCEF NY office.<ref name=Brownmiller1999/>
==Feminist activism and writing== By early 1968, Hanisch had secured the SCEF offices for the weekly meetings of the New York Radical Women, and it remained their base until the group dissolved in the early 70's.<ref name=Brownmiller1999>Brownmiller, Susan (1999). ''In Our Time: Memoir of a Revolution''. Dial Press, pp. 20–21, 23.</ref>
She co-founded and currently co-edits with Kathy Scarbrough ''Meeting Ground online'', the third version of "Meeting Ground." The statement of purpose from 1977 describes itself as providing "an ongoing place to hammer out ideas about theory, strategy and tactics for the women’s liberation movement and for the general radical movement of working men and women."<ref>[http://meetinggroundonline.org/about-meeting-ground/ ''Meeting Ground online''] website "about page" with January 1977 statement of purpose, ''accessed August 31, 2014.''</ref>
In 2013 Hanish, along with Scarbrough, [[Ti-Grace Atkinson]] and [[Kathie Sarachild]] initiated "Forbidden Discourse: The Silencing of Feminist Criticism of 'Gender'", which they described as an "open statement from 48 radical feminists from seven countries".<ref>[http://meetinggroundonline.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/GENDER-Statement-InterActive-930.pdf Forbidden Discourse: The Silencing of Feminist Criticism of 'Gender'"], at ''Meeting Ground online'', August 12, 2013, updated with more signatures September 20, 2013.</ref> In August 2014 Michelle Goldberg in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' described it as expressing their “alarm” at “threats and attacks, some of them physical, on individuals and organizations daring to challenge the currently fashionable concept of gender.”<ref>Goldberg, Michelle (August 4, 2014). [http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/04/woman-2 "What Is a Woman? The dispute between radical feminism and transgenderism"], ''[[The New Yorker]]''.</ref>

{{History of Indonesia}} '''Dalem Samprangan''' was a king of [[Bali]] who governed under the suzerainty of the [[Javanese people|Javanese]] [[Majapahit]] Empire (1293-c. 1527), and belonged to a dynasty of immigrants from [[Java]]. The exact dating of his reign is unclear; the sources point at either the second half of the 14th century or the early 16th century.
==Reign==
According to the 18th-century chronicle [[Babad Dalem]],<ref>I Wayan Warna et al. (tr.), ''Babad Dalem. Teks dan Terjemahan''. Dinas Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan Daerah Tingkat I Bali.</ref> Dalem Samprangan succeeded his father [[Sri Aji Kresna Kepakisan]] who had been established as vassal king by Majapahit after the conquest of Bali in 1343. His residence was [[Samprangan]] in the present-day [[Gianyar]] regency, to the southeast of the ancient royal seat Bedaulu.<ref>Margaret J. Wiener, ''Visible and invisible realms: Power, magic, and colonial conquest in Bali''. Chicago & London: Chicago University Press 1995, p. 110.</ref> The chronicle characterizes him as an incompetent and vain figure. He spent much time on his outward appearance, and let his ministers wait in the council hall for him to show up. This behaviour irritated the grandees of the kingdom. After waiting for hours in vain one morning, one of them, Kubon Klapa, left the palace in anger and looked up Dalem Samprangan's youngest brother Ketut, who was a well-known gambler. He persuaded the prince to take royal titles and offered him his residence in [[Gelgel, Indonesia|Gelgel]], a village in the present-day [[Klungkung]] residency, near the south coast. In that way, the Samprangan palace quickly lapsed into obscurity, while Gelgel rose as the political centre of the island under the new king [[Dalem Ketut]].<ref>C.C. Berg, ''De middeljavaansche historische traditië''. Santpoort: Mees 1927, pp. 123-4.</ref> No more is heard in the ''Babad Dalem'' about Samprangan which became a minor village immediately to the east of [[Gianyar]].<ref>Adrian Vickers, "Central Bali: Gianyar Regency", in Eric Oey (ed.), ''Bali: Island of the gods''. Berkeley: Periplus, p. 113.</ref>
==Conflict with Dalem Tarukan==
A complex of legendary texts called ''Babad Pulasari'' relate the fortunes of Dalem Samprangan's other brother Dalem Tarukan, who had a residence close to modern [[Ubud]]. He fell out with his royal brother which resulted in a series of internecine wars on the island. At length, Dalem Tarukan was defeated, and his descendants were demoted from the [[Ksatria]] caste. Certain Balinese texts date the defeat of Tarukan in 1502.<ref>http://vxu.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:206791/FULLTEXT01 , p. 20.</ref> This is incompatible with the ''Babad Dalem'', which indicates Dalem Samprangan about one generation after the Majapahit conquest of 1343. The historical background of these persons and events is therefore uncertain.
==Place in the list of Balinese rulers==
In the central Balinese temple [[Pura Besakih]], the most important shrine is Pura Padharman Dalem Gelgel, which honours a series of six ancient Balinese kings. After Dewa Tegal Besung (often identified as Dalem Ketut), who is accorded a ''meru'' (tower-like structure) with 11 roofs, Dewa Samprangan follows with a ''meru'' with 9 roofs, in turn followed by Dewa Enggong ([[Dalem Baturenggong]]) and three later kings.<ref>David Stuart-Fox, ''Pura Besakih: Tempel, religion and society in Bali''. Leiden: KITLV Press 2002, p. 118.</ref> Dalem Samprangan is also listed as king in the early religious text ''Usana Bali'', as successor of Ken Angrok and predecessor of Dalem Baturenggong.<ref>R. Friederich, "De Oesana Bali", ''Tijdschrift voor Neerland's Indië'' 9-3 1847, p. 286. [[Ken Arok|Ken Angrok]] is otherwise known as the founder king of [[Singhasari]] on [[Java]]</ref> All this complicates the question of his original place in the succession of Balinese rulers.
