revision.text:
{{short description|1st-century Roman Catholic saint}} {{Infobox saint |name= Saint Julian the Hospitaller |birth_date =perhaps 7 AD |death_date=? |feast_day= 12 February |venerated_in= [[Roman Catholic Church]] |image= Saintjulianghirlandaio.JPG |imagesize= 250px |caption= Saint Julian, from a [[fresco]] by [[Domenico Ghirlandaio]] |birth_place= |death_place= |titles= |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes=Carrying a leper through a river; ferryman; hart; holding an oar; man listening to a talking stag; oar; stag; with [[Jesus]] and [[Martha|Saint Martha]] as patrons of travelers; young hunter with a stag; young man killing his parents in bed; young man wearing a fur-lined cloak, sword, and gloves; young, well-dressed man holding a hawk on his finger |patronage= Boatmen, carnival workers, childless people, circus workers, clowns, ferrymen, fiddlers, fiddle players, hospitallers, hotel-keepers, hunters, innkeepers, jugglers, knights, murderers, pilgrims, shepherds, to obtain lodging while traveling, travelers, wandering musicians, [[St. Julian's]]; [[Macerata]] |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= }} '''Julian the Hospitaller''' is a [[Roman Catholic]] saint. ==History== The earliest known reference to Julian dates to the late twelfth century.[http://d.lib.rochester.edu/teams/text/whatley-saints-lives-in-middle-english-collections-life-of-st-julian-hospitaller-introduction "The Life of St. Julian the Hospitaller: Introduction", ''Saints' Lives in Middle English Collections'', (E. Gordon Whatley, Anne B. Thompson, and Robert K. Upchurch, eds.) 2004] {{ISBN|1-58044-089-4}} There are three main theories of his origin: * Born in [[Le Mans]], France, possibly from confusion with [[Saint Julian of Le Mans]] * Born in [[Ath]], Belgium, around 7 AD * Born in [[Naples]], Italy The location of the hospitals built by him is also debated between the banks of the River [[Gardon]] in [[Provence]] and an island near the River [[Potenza (river)|Potenza]] heading to [[Macerata]]. He was known as the patron of the cities of [[Ghent]] and [[Macerata]]. The [[Lord's Prayer|Paternoster]] (Our Father prayer) of St. Julian can be found as early as 1353 in [[Giovanni Boccaccio|Boccaccio]]'s ''[[Decameron]]'', and is still passed on by word of mouth throughout some places in Italy. The account is included the 13th-century ''[[The Golden Legend|Leggenda Aurea]]'' of [[Genoa|Genoan]] [[Giacomo da Varazze]], a [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] priest. Beautiful stained glass depicting St. Julian by an unknown artist in the [[Cathedral of Chartres]] also dates back to the 13th century. Early [[fresco]] paintings of him are found in the [[Cathedral of Trento]] (14th century) and the Palazzo Comunale di Assisi. ==Golden Legend== [[Image:Saint Julian Taddeo Gaddi.JPG|thumb|left|150px|Saint Julian. [[Taddeo Gaddi]], 14th century.]] According to de Varazze, on the night Julian was born, his father, a man of noble blood, saw pagan [[witch]]es secretly lay a curse on the boy that would make him kill both his parents. His father wanted to get rid of the child, but his mother did not let him do so. As the boy grew into a handsome young man, his mother would often burst into tears because of the sin her son was destined to commit. When he finally found out the reason for her tears, he swore he "would never commit such a sin" and "with great belief in [[Christ]] went off full of courage" as far away from his parents as he could. Some versions say that it was his mother who told him at the age of 10, while others say it was a stag he met in the forest while hunting (a situation used in depicting St. Julian in statues and pictures). After fifty days of walking he finally reached [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] where he married a "good woman", said to be a wealthy widow. Twenty years later, his parents decided to go look for their now thirty-year-old son. When they arrived, they visited the altar of [[James, son of Zebedee|St. James]], and "as soon as they came out of the church they met a woman sitting on a chair outside, whom the pilgrims greeted and asked, for Jesus' love, whether she would host them for the night as they were tired." She let them in and told them that her husband, Julian, was out hunting. (This is why he is also known as the patron of hunters.) The mother and father were overjoyed to have found their son, as was Julian's wife. "She took care of them well and had them rest in her and Julian's bed." But ''the enemy'' went off seeking Julian and told him: 'I have sour news for you. While you are here, hunting, your wife is in bed embracing another man. There they are right now, still sleeping.'" De Verazze continues: "And Julian felt deep sadness and his face drew into a frown. He rode back home, went to his bed and found a man and a woman sleeping in it. He drew his sword and killed them both. He was about to take off and never again set foot in that land, but as he was leaving he saw his wife sitting among the other women. She told him: 'There are your mother and father resting in your room.' And so Julian knew, and fell into a rage. 'The shrewd enemy lied to me when he said my wife was betraying me', and while kissing their wounds he cried 'Better had I never been born, for I am cursed in soul and body.' And his good wife comforted him and said 'Have faith in Christ Almighty, a stream of life and mercy.' They had no children... Gold and silver they had a lot... And after seeking redemption in Rome, Julian built seven hospitals and twenty-five houses. And the poor started flowing to him, to Jesus' Almighty's love." [[Image:Quattrino Macerata.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Papal States scudo|Quattrino]] of Macerata depicting Saint Julian]] De Verazze continues: "''The enemy'' conspired again to ruin Julian—disguised as a weak pilgrim, he was let in by Julian with the others. At midnight he woke up and made a mess of the house." The following morning Julian saw the damage and swore never to let in anyone else in his home. He was so furious he had everyone leave. "And [[Jesus]] went to him, again as a pilgrim, seeking rest. He asked humbly, in the name of God, for shelter. But Julian answered with contempt: 'I shall not let you in. Go away, for the other night I had my home so vandalized that I shall never let you in.' And Christ told him 'Hold my walking-stick, please.' Julian, embarrassed, went to take the stick, and it stuck to his hands. And Julian recognized him at once and said 'He tricked me, ''the enemy'' who does not want me to be your faithful servant. But I shall embrace you, I do not care about him; and for your love I shall give shelter to whoever needs.' He knelt and Jesus forgave him, and Julian asked, full of repentance, forgiveness for his wife and parents. Some versions skip the second mistake and tell of an [[angel]] visiting Julian and announcing to him that he is forgiven. [[Image:St-Julien Chapelle statue 0707.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Statue of Saint Julian in the church of Saint-Julien ([[Puy-de-Dôme]], France).]] [[File:Statue, The Church of St Julian the Hospitaller, Wellow - geograph.org.uk - 1288959.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Statue at the Church of St Julian the Hospitaller in [[Wellow, Somerset]].]] ==Veneration in Malta== Devotion to St. Julian started in the [[Malta|Maltese]] Islands in the 15th century after the discovery of his relics in the city of [[Macerata]]. It was introduced by the noble family of De Astis, high-ranking in Malta at the time, who had strong connections with the [[Bishop of Macerata]]. Three churches were built in his honor before the arrival of the [[Knights Hospitaller|Knights]]: in [[Tabija]], towards [[Mdina]]; in [[Luqa]]; and in [[Senglea]] (Isla). This last one had a storage room for [[hunters]], and served to popularize this devotion through the sailors arriving at the Three Cities. In the 16th century there existed a hospital, ''Ospedale di San Giuliano'', in the Citadel in [[Gozo]], showing a wide devotion to the saint. Being an order of hospitaliers, the [[Knights of St. John]] helped widen further this devotion. In 1539 they rebuilt the church in Senglea and in 1590 built another church in the parish of [[Birkirkara]], a section that since then was called [[St. Julian's]]. In 1891 the church was made a parish, the only one ever dedicated to the saint in Malta. ===Patronage=== St. Julian was invoked as the patron of hospitality by travelers on a journey and far from home pray hoping to find safe lodging. ==Julian the Hospitaller in literature and music== * [[Gustave Flaubert]] wrote a short story entitled "La légende de Saint-Julien l'Hospitalier", included in his ''[[Three Tales (novel)|Three Tales]]''. * Subject of an opera by [[Camille Erlanger]], ''La légende de Saint-Julien l'Hospitalier'' (1888) based on the Flaubert story. * Subject of an opera by [[Riccardo Zandonai]], ''Giuliano'' (1928) with libretto by Arturo Rossato, based on stories by [[Jacobus de Voragine]] and [[Gustave Flaubert]]. * [[Walter Wangerin, Jr.]] wrote a novel, classified as historical fiction, titled "Saint Julian." * One of the tales in [[Giovanni Bocaccio]]'s [[Decameron]] is named ''The miracle of St. Julian'', and is about a faithful devoté of St. Julian whose faith is put to test during a travel. * On "''The Chronicles of Julian, the Hospitaller''", a historical fiction set at the turn of the first millennium, Saint Julian meets the devil throughout his life, leading to an ultimate confrontation at construction site of the [[Ponte della Maddalena|Bridge of Borgo a Mozzano]], in [[Lucca]], Tuscany. {{Cite book|title=The Chronicles of Julian, The Hospitaller|last=Bernardi|first=Eduardo|publisher=Higuma Limited, NZ.|year=2018|isbn=978-0-473-43697-1|location=New Zealand|pages=Books1-5}} The Life of Saint Julian Hospitaller, (translated by Tony Devaney Morinelli). Earliest text: "La Vie de saint Julien"[http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/julian.html Fordham.edu] ==Placenames== * [[St. Julian's]] – a town in [[Malta]] * [[San Zulian]] – a church in [[Venice]] * [[São Julião (disambiguation)|São Julião]] – other placenames in [[Portugal]] * [[Saint-Julien-le-Pauvre]] – a 12th-century Gothic church in [[Paris]] * [[San Julián (disambiguation)|San Julián]] * St. Julian, an historic housing complex in Ashfield, NSW, Australia.A Short Walk Through Ashfield's Past. [http://www.ashfield.nsw.gov.au/files/your_council/ashfields_past.pdf Ashfield History], accessed 23/10/10. ==See also== * [[List of saints]] * [[Saint Julian (disambiguation)|Saint Julian]] (other saints with the same name) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== {{Commons category|Saint Julian the Hospitaller}} *[http://www.sdcmuseum.org/ SDCmuseum.org], St. Julian's. Translated from Maltese with permission. ==External links== * {{wikisource-inline|Gesta Romanorum Vol. I (1871)/Of venial Sin|Of venial Sin (The legend of Saint Julian)}}, from [[Gesta Romanorum]] * Julian the Hospitaller was mentioned in two important mediaeval scripts.
Here are English translations for [http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/goldenlegend/GoldenLegend-Volume3.htm#Julian The Golden Legend (Volume III)] and [http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/julian.html La Vie de saint Julien] Translated by Tony Devaney Morinelli * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051030111303/http://www.wcr.ab.ca/columns/tedfitzgerald/2004/fitzgerald020904.shtml This patron saint of innkeepers was welcome at court] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070717192727/http://www.catholic-forum.com/saints/saintj31.htm Julian the Hospitaller] *[http://www.lib.rochester.edu/camelot/teams/whjulintro.htm The Life of St. Julian the Hospitaller] *{{it icon}} [http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/36750 San Giuliano l'ospitaliere] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Julian The Hospitaller}} [[Category:Italian Roman Catholic saints]] [[Category:French Roman Catholic saints]] [[Category:Christian folklore]] [[Category:Angelic visionaries]]

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Kennedy Center Honors | current_awards = | image = Kennedy center honors logo.svg | caption = Logotype symbolizing "a spectrum of many skills within the performing arts" | description = Lifetime contributions to [[Culture of the United States|American culture]] through the [[performing arts]]. | presenter = [[Board of Trustees of the Kennedy Center]] | country = US | location = | year = 1978 | year2 = | website = [http://www.kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors/ Kennedy Center Honors] }}
[[Image:Kennedy center honors 2006.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The 2006 honorees at the Kennedy Center on December 6, 2006, with President [[George W. Bush]] and First Lady [[Laura Bush]]. From left, [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]], [[Steven Spielberg]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Zubin Mehta]], [[Smokey Robinson]], Vice President [[Dick Cheney]], and [[Lynne Cheney]].]]
The '''Kennedy Center Honors''' is an annual honor given to those in the [[performing arts]] for their lifetime of contributions to [[Culture of the United States|American culture]] (regardless of their citizenship). The honors have been presented annually since 1978, culminating each December in a star-studded gala celebrating the honorees in the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]] Opera House.<ref name=about>[http://www.kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors/about/home.html "About the Honors"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516004214/http://kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors/about/home.html |date=2008-05-16 }} Kennedy Center. Accessed October 4, 2015.</ref>
==History== [[George Stevens Jr.]] created the Kennedy Center Honors with the late [[Nick Vanoff]], and produced the first gala in 1978. He was the producer and co-writer through the 2014 awards,<ref>Harris, Paul. [https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/george-stevens-jr-to-end-37-year-run-as-kennedy-center-honors-producer-1201373481/ "George Stevens Jr. to End 37-Year Run as Kennedy Center Honors Producer"] ''Variety'', December 7, 2014</ref> after which he sold the production rights to the Kennedy Center.
The Kennedy Center Honors started in 1977, after that year's 10th-anniversary White House reception and Kennedy Center program for the [[American Film Institute]] (AFI). [[Roger L. Stevens]], the founding chairman of the Kennedy Center, asked George Stevens, Jr., (no relation), the founding director of the AFI, to hold an event for the Center. George Stevens asked Isaac Stern to become involved, and then "pitched" the idea to the television network [[CBS]], who "bought it." With the announcement of the first honors event and honorees, CBS vice president for specials Bernie Sofronski stated:<ref>Crews, Chip. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/12/26/AR2005122600801_pf.html "The Honors, Take 2"] ''Washington Post'', December 27, 2005</ref><ref>Shales, Tom. "Crowning America's Culture Superstars", The Washington Post, September 28, 1978, p. B1</ref>
{{quote|George [Stevens] came to us with this. What turned us on is that this is the only show of its kind. In Europe and most countries, they have ways of honoring their actors and their athletes. England has its command performances for the queen. We see this as a national honoring of people who have contributed to society, not someone who happens to have a pop record hit at the moment ... Our intention is not to do just another award show. We're going to make an effort in terms of a real special.}}
The first host was [[Leonard Bernstein]] in 1978, followed by [[Eric Sevareid]] in 1979 and [[Beverly Sills]] in 1980. [[Walter Cronkite]] hosted from 1981 to 2002 and [[Caroline Kennedy]] hosted from 2003 until 2012. [[Glenn Close]] hosted in 2013 and [[Stephen Colbert]] hosted from 2014 to 2016.<ref>McGlone, Peggy. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2014/11/19/stephen-colbert-will-host-37th-annual-kennedy-center-honors/# "Stephen Colbert will host 37th annual Kennedy Center Honors"] ''Washington Post'', November 19, 2014</ref><ref>Park, Andrea. [https://www.cbsnews.com/news/how-to-watch-the-kennedy-center-honors-2016/ "Kennedy Center Honors 2016"] cbsnews.com, December 27, 2016</ref> There was no formal host in 2017, though Caroline Kennedy delivered an introduction.
Ricky Kirshner and Glenn Weiss of White Cherry Entertainment were selected as Executive Producers of the 38th annual Kennedy Center Honors (2015) after George Stevens, Jr. stepped down.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/style-blog/wp/2015/05/05/tony-awards-team-chosen-to-produce-2015-kennedy-center-honors/ "Tony Awards Team Chosen"] ''Washington Post'', May 5, 2015</ref>
This is one of the few awards shows that does not air live (with the exception of closed-circuit venues), but a re-edited version lasting approximately two hours is normally televised on [[CBS]] after Christmas.<ref>[https://www.cbsnews.com/news/kennedy-center-honors-2017-how-to-watch-on-cbs/ "Kennedy Center Honors 2017: How to watch online and on TV, start time and pre-show"] cbsnews.com, December 26, 2017</ref><ref>[https://www.kennedy-center.org/Content/pdfs/pages/specialevents/2017HonorsPressRelease.pdf "2017 Honors"] kennedy-center.org, December 3, 2017</ref>
===Selection process=== Honoree recommendations are accepted from the general public,<ref>[http://www.kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors/ Honors] kennedy-center.org</ref> and the Kennedy Center initiated a Special Honors Advisory Committee, which comprises two members of the Board of Trustees as well as past Honorees and distinguished artists. The Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees selects the Honoree recipients based on excellence in music, dance, theater, opera, motion pictures or television.<ref name="kennedy-center.org">[https://www.kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors/2015HonorsPressRelease.pdf Press Release"] kennedy-center.org</ref> The selections are typically announced sometime between July and September.
==The events== The invitation-only weekend-long ceremony includes the Chairman's Luncheon, State Department dinner, White House reception, and the Honors gala performances and supper.
Surrounded by the Honorees, the luncheon is held on Saturday at the [[Kennedy Center]], with a welcoming speech by the Chairman of the Board of Trustees. At that evening's reception and dinner at the [[United States Department of State|State Department]], presided over by the [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], the Honorees are introduced and the Honors medallions are presented by the Chairman of the Board.<ref name="kennedy-center.org"/> The wide rainbow-colored ribbon then hung around the necks of the recipients, and prominently noticeable when the events are televised, symbolizes "a spectrum of many skills within the performing arts" according to creator [[Ivan Chermayeff]].<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/05/AR2008120500948.html Interview] in [[The Washington Post]] 2008-12-07</ref>
On Sunday, there is an early-evening [[White House]] reception<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mrs-o.com/newdata/2011/12/4/a-vision-in-blue.html|title=A Vision in Blue|publisher=Mrs. O|date=2011-12-04|accessdate=2015-12-30}}</ref> hosted by the President of the United States and the First Lady, followed by the Honors gala performance at the Kennedy Center and supper.
For the 2015 gala performance, President [[Barack Obama]] did attend, after addressing the nation in a live telecast.<ref>McGlone, Peggy. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2015/12/06/president-obama-to-skip-kennedy-center-honors-performance/# "President Obama will be late to Kennedy Center Honors performance"] ''Washington Post'', December 6, 2015</ref> There have been four occasions where the President did not attend the gala performances: President [[Jimmy Carter]] did not attend the December 1979 gala performance during the hostage crisis,<ref>Gamarekian, Barbara. "Kennedy Center Honors Five For Life]Achievements in Arts: Audience of Over 2,000 'She Led a Revolt' White House Reception", ''The New York Times'', December 3, 1979, p. C14. "Mrs. Carter: 'As you know President Carter has had to cancel his public appearances.'"</ref> President [[George H.W. Bush]] did not attend in December 1989 and President [[Bill Clinton]] did not attend in 1994.<ref>McGlone, Peggy. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2015/12/06/president-obama-to-skip-kennedy-center-honors-performance/# "President Obama to skip Kennedy Center Honors performance"] ''Washington Post'', December 6, 2015</ref><ref>Pareles, John. [http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1994-12-25/entertainment/9412280359_1_kennedy-center-honors-morton-gould-arts "Performers Receive Kennedy Center Awards"] ''Sun Sentinel'', December 25, 1994</ref>
On August 19, 2017, the White House announced that President [[Donald Trump]] and the first lady, Melania Trump, have decided not to participate in events honoring recipients of the 2017 Kennedy Center Honors awards to "allow the honorees to celebrate without any political distraction."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-to-skip-kennedy-center-arts-awards/2017/08/19/621e7a5c-84d6-11e7-9e7a-20fa8d7a0db6_story.html "Trump to skip Kennedy Center arts award."] ''Washington Post'', August 19, 2017</ref> At the 2017 ceremony, held on December 3, 2017, President and Mrs. Trump did not attend. Caroline Kennedy was the hostess and presented the honorees. The traditional dinner at the State Department on the Saturday evening before the ceremony was hosted by Secretary of State [[Rex Tillerson]] and the White House reception was canceled.<ref name=2017gala>McGlone, Peggy. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/2017/12/03/ee27f8f8-d881-11e7-b1a8-62589434a581_story.html "At the Kennedy Center Honors, plenty of politics make up for Trump’s playing hooky"] ''Washington Post'', December 3, 2017</ref>
==Recipients== [[Image:2005 Kennedy Center honorees.jpg|thumb|250px|2005 Kennedy Center Honorees [[Julie Harris (American actress)|Julie Harris]], [[Robert Redford]], [[Tina Turner]], [[Suzanne Farrell]], and [[Tony Bennett]], with President [[George W. Bush]] and First Lady [[Laura Bush]], in the Blue Room at the White House, December 4, 2005.]] [[Image:Barack Obama speaks to Led Zeppelin.jpg|thumb|250px| The surviving members of [[Led Zeppelin]] were honored in 2012 and are pictured here with President [[Barack Obama]].]] There have been 213 recipients to date of the Kennedy Center Honors Awards during the Honor's 40 years (as of 2017), although the one given to [[Bill Cosby]] in 1998 was rescinded in 2018, following his sexual assault conviction.<ref name="cosbyrescind">{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/bill-cosby-kennedy-center-honors-212925295.html |title=Bill Cosby's Kennedy Center Honors, Mark Twain Prize Revoked |publisher=yahoo.com |date=2018-05-08 |accessdate=2018-05-08}}</ref> The vast majority have been bestowed on individuals. On ten occasions since 1985, awards have been presented to duos or groups, including three married couples who were actors: [[Hume Cronyn]] and [[Jessica Tandy]], [[Paul Newman]] and [[Joanne Woodward]], and [[Ossie Davis]] and [[Ruby Dee]]. The dancers [[Fayard Nicholas]] and [[Harold Nicholas]] of the [[Nicholas Brothers]] were honored, along with three [[musical theater]] songwriting duos: [[Alan Jay Lerner]] and [[Frederick Loewe]], [[Betty Comden]] and [[Adolph Green]], and [[John Kander]] and [[Fred Ebb]]. The musicians of three [[Band (rock and pop)|rock groups]] were also awarded: [[Pete Townshend]] and [[Roger Daltrey]] of [[The Who]], [[John Paul Jones]], [[Jimmy Page]] and [[Robert Plant]] of [[Led Zeppelin]], and [[Don Henley]], [[Timothy B. Schmit]], [[Joe Walsh]] and (posthumously) [[Glenn Frey]] of the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]].
The 2018 award ceremony will present the honor, for the first time, to the creators of the musical ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]'': Lin-Manuel Miranda, Thomas Kail, Andy Blankenbuehler and Alex Lacamoire for "trailblazing creators of a transformative work that defies category."<ref name=cher>Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/article/hamilton-creators-lin-manuel-miranda-thomas-kail-andy-blankenbuehler-alex-lacamoire-will-receive-special-kennedy-center-honors# " 'Hamilton' Creators Lin-Manuel Miranda, Thomas Kail, Andy Blankenbuehler, Alex Lacamoire Will Receive Special Kennedy Center Honors"] Playbill, July 25, 2018</ref>
===1970s=== * 1978 – [[Marian Anderson]], [[Fred Astaire]], [[George Balanchine]], [[Richard Rodgers]], and [[Arthur Rubinstein]] * 1979 – [[Aaron Copland]], [[Ella Fitzgerald]], [[Henry Fonda]], [[Martha Graham]], and [[Tennessee Williams]]
===1980s=== * 1980 – [[Leonard Bernstein]], [[James Cagney]], [[Agnes de Mille]], [[Lynn Fontanne]], and [[Leontyne Price]] * 1981 – [[Count Basie]], [[Cary Grant]], [[Helen Hayes]], [[Jerome Robbins]], and [[Rudolf Serkin]] * 1982 – [[George Abbott]], [[Lillian Gish]], [[Benny Goodman]], [[Gene Kelly]], and [[Eugene Ormandy]] * 1983 – [[Katherine Dunham]], [[Elia Kazan]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[James Stewart]], and [[Virgil Thomson]] * 1984 – [[Lena Horne]], [[Danny Kaye]], [[Gian Carlo Menotti]], [[Arthur Miller]], and [[Isaac Stern]] * 1985 – [[Merce Cunningham]], [[Irene Dunne]], [[Bob Hope]], [[Alan Jay Lerner]] & [[Frederick Loewe]], and [[Beverly Sills]] * 1986 – [[Lucille Ball]], [[Ray Charles]], [[Hume Cronyn]] & [[Jessica Tandy]], [[Yehudi Menuhin]], and [[Antony Tudor]] * 1987 – [[Perry Como]], [[Bette Davis]], [[Sammy Davis Jr.]], [[Nathan Milstein]], and [[Alwin Nikolais]] * 1988 – [[Alvin Ailey]], [[George Burns]], [[Myrna Loy]], [[Alexander Schneider]], and [[Roger L. Stevens]] * 1989 – [[Harry Belafonte]], [[Claudette Colbert]], [[Alexandra Danilova]], [[Mary Martin]], and [[William Schuman]]
===1990s=== * 1990 – [[Dizzy Gillespie]], [[Katharine Hepburn]], [[Risë Stevens]], [[Jule Styne]], and [[Billy Wilder]] * 1991 – [[Roy Acuff]], [[Betty Comden]] & [[Adolph Green]], [[Fayard Nicholas|Fayard]] & [[Harold Nicholas]], [[Gregory Peck]], and [[Robert Shaw (conductor)|Robert Shaw]] * 1992 – [[Lionel Hampton]], [[Paul Newman]] & [[Joanne Woodward]], [[Ginger Rogers]], [[Mstislav Rostropovich]], and [[Paul Taylor (choreographer)|Paul Taylor]] * 1993 – [[Johnny Carson]], [[Arthur Mitchell (dancer)|Arthur Mitchell]], [[Georg Solti]], [[Stephen Sondheim]], and [[Marion Williams]] * 1994 – [[Kirk Douglas]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Morton Gould]], [[Harold Prince]], and [[Pete Seeger]] * 1995 – [[Jacques d'Amboise (dancer)|Jacques d'Amboise]], [[Marilyn Horne]], [[B.B. King]], [[Sidney Poitier]], and [[Neil Simon]] * 1996 – [[Edward Albee]], [[Benny Carter]], [[Johnny Cash]], [[Jack Lemmon]], and [[Maria Tallchief]] * 1997 – [[Lauren Bacall]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Charlton Heston]], [[Jessye Norman]], and [[Edward Villella]] * 1998 – [[Bill Cosby|<s>Bill Cosby</s>]] (rescinded in 2018),<ref>{{cite web|title=Kennedy Center rescinds Bill Cosby's Honors and Twain awards|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2018/05/07/kennedy-center-rescinds-honors-twain-awards-given-to-bill-cosby/|publisher=The Washington Post|date=May 7, 2018}}</ref> [[Fred Ebb]] & [[John Kander]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[André Previn]], and [[Shirley Temple|Shirley Temple Black]] * 1999 – [[Victor Borge]], [[Sean Connery]], [[Judith Jamison]], [[Jason Robards]], and [[Stevie Wonder]]
===2000s=== [[File:Kennedy Center honorees 2009 WhiteHouse Photo.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Kennedy Center honorees 2009 [[Mel Brooks]], [[Dave Brubeck]], [[Grace Bumbry]], [[Robert De Niro]], and [[Bruce Springsteen]], with President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama in the Blue Room, White House, Dec. 6, 2009.]] * 2000 – [[Mikhail Baryshnikov]], [[Chuck Berry]], [[Plácido Domingo]], [[Clint Eastwood]], and [[Angela Lansbury]] * 2001 – [[Julie Andrews]], [[Van Cliburn]], [[Quincy Jones]], [[Jack Nicholson]], and [[Luciano Pavarotti]] * 2002 – [[James Earl Jones]], [[James Levine]], [[Chita Rivera]], [[Paul Simon]], and [[Elizabeth Taylor]] * 2003 – [[James Brown]], [[Carol Burnett]], [[Loretta Lynn]], [[Mike Nichols]], and [[Itzhak Perlman]] * 2004 – [[Warren Beatty]], [[Ossie Davis]] & [[Ruby Dee]], [[Elton John]], [[Joan Sutherland]], and [[John Williams]] * 2005 – [[Tony Bennett]], [[Suzanne Farrell]], [[Julie Harris (actress)|Julie Harris]], [[Robert Redford]], and [[Tina Turner]] * 2006 – [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]], [[Zubin Mehta]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Smokey Robinson]], and [[Steven Spielberg]] * 2007 – [[Leon Fleisher]], [[Steve Martin]], [[Diana Ross]], [[Martin Scorsese]], and [[Brian Wilson]] * 2008 – [[Morgan Freeman]], [[George Jones]], [[Barbra Streisand]], [[Twyla Tharp]], and [[The Who]] ([[Pete Townshend]] and [[Roger Daltrey]]) * 2009 – [[Mel Brooks]], [[Dave Brubeck]], [[Grace Bumbry]], [[Robert De Niro]], and [[Bruce Springsteen]]
===2010s=== * 2010 – [[Merle Haggard]], [[Jerry Herman]], [[Bill T. Jones]], [[Paul McCartney]], and [[Oprah Winfrey]] * 2011 – [[Barbara Cook]], [[Neil Diamond]], [[Yo-Yo Ma]], [[Sonny Rollins]], and [[Meryl Streep]]<ref>[http://www.kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors/ "Barbara Cook, Neil Diamond, Yo-Yo Ma, Sonny Rollins & Meryl Streep to Receive 34th Annual Kennedy Center Honors"] kennedy-center.org, accessed September 6, 2011</ref> * 2012 – [[Buddy Guy]], [[Dustin Hoffman]], [[Led Zeppelin]] ([[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]], [[Jimmy Page]] and [[Robert Plant]]), [[David Letterman]], and [[Natalia Makarova]]<ref>Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/169937-Dustin-Hoffman-David-Letterman-Natalia-Makarova-Buddy-Guy-Led-Zeppelin-Are-Kennedy-Center-Honorees "Dustin Hoffman, David Letterman, Natalia Makarova, Buddy Guy, Led Zeppelin Are Kennedy Center Honorees"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109035635/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/169937-Dustin-Hoffman-David-Letterman-Natalia-Makarova-Buddy-Guy-Led-Zeppelin-Are-Kennedy-Center-Honorees |date=2012-11-09 }} playbill.com, September 12, 2012</ref> * 2013 – [[Martina Arroyo]], [[Herbie Hancock]], [[Billy Joel]], [[Shirley MacLaine]], and [[Carlos Santana]]<ref>Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/182034-Martina-Arroyo-Herbie-Hancock-Billy-Joel-Shirley-MacLaine-and-Carlos-Santana-Are-2013-Kennedy-Center-Honorees?tsrc=hpt2 "Martina Arroyo, Herbie Hancock, Billy Joel, Shirley MacLaine and Carlos Santana Are 2013 Kennedy Center Honorees"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021201552/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/182034-Martina-Arroyo-Herbie-Hancock-Billy-Joel-Shirley-MacLaine-and-Carlos-Santana-Are-2013-Kennedy-Center-Honorees?tsrc=hpt2 |date=2013-10-21 }} playbill.com, September 12, 2013</ref> * 2014 – [[Al Green]], [[Tom Hanks]], [[Patricia McBride]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], and [[Lily Tomlin]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/biz/news/tom-hanks-lily-tomlin-sting-to-receive-kennedy-center-honors-1201297630/|title=Tom Hanks, Lily Tomlin, Sting to Receive Kennedy Center Honors|first=Paul|last=Harris|work=Variety|date=2014-09-04|accessdate=2014-09-04}}</ref> * 2015 – [[Carole King]], [[George Lucas]], [[Rita Moreno]], [[Seiji Ozawa]], and [[Cicely Tyson]]<ref>Viagas, Robert. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/carole-king-cicely-tyson-rita-moreno-and-more-named-2015-kennedy-center-honorees-353316 "Carole King, Cicely Tyson, Rita Moreno and More Named 2015 Kennedy Center Honorees"] playbill.com, July 15, 2015</ref> * 2016 – [[Martha Argerich]], [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]] ([[Don Henley]], [[Glenn Frey]], [[Timothy B. Schmit]], [[Joe Walsh]]).<ref name="Frey">{{cite press release|url=http://www.kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors/2016HonorsPressRelease.pdf|title=Martha Argerich, Eagles, Al Pacino, Mavis Staples, James Taylor To Receive 39th Annual Kennedy Center Honors|publisher=Kennedy Center Honors|date=June 23, 2016|accessdate=July 25, 2016}}</ref> [[Al Pacino]], [[Mavis Staples]], and [[James Taylor]]<ref name=eagles>Clark, Cindy. [https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2015/11/04/kennedy-center-postpones-honors-eagles/75189296/ "Kennedy Center postpones Honors to Eagles"] ''USAToday'', November 4, 2015</ref><ref>Hipes, Patrick. [http://deadline.com/2016/06/kennedy-center-honors-2016-al-pacinio-eagles-james-taylor-mavis-staples-martha-argerich-1201778011/ "Kennedy Center Honors: Al Pacino, Eagles, James Taylor & More"] ''Deadline'', June 23, 2016</ref> * 2017 – [[Carmen de Lavallade]], [[Gloria Estefan]], [[LL Cool J]], [[Norman Lear]], and [[Lionel Richie]] * 2018 – [[Cher]], [[Philip Glass]], [[Reba McEntire]], [[Wayne Shorter]], and the creators of ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton: An American Musical]]'' ([[Lin-Manuel Miranda]], [[Thomas Kail]], [[Alex Lacamoire]], and [[Andy Blankenbuehler]])<ref name=cher/>
==Prospective honorees who declined, canceled, or postponed== Pianist [[Vladimir Horowitz]] was to be an honoree, but the selection committee withdrew the offer when Horowitz conditioned his acceptance on being honored alone and at 4 in the afternoon.<ref name="washpost">Crews, Chip. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/12/26/AR2005122600801_pf.html "The Honors, Take 2"] ''The Washington Post'', December 27, 2005</ref>
Actress [[Katharine Hepburn]] declined the committee's first offer, though she relented in 1990.<ref name="washpost"/>
[[Doris Day]] repeatedly turned down the honors because her fear of flying prevented her from attending the ceremony.<ref>Pollock, Allen.[http://www.dorisday.com/about "About Doris"] www.dorisday.com</ref>
When considering [[Irving Berlin]] for the 1987 awards because of criticism for overlooking him, the Center was informed that Berlin wanted to be honored only if he surpassed his 100th birthday (which would not be until May 1988). Also, he was in failing health, used a wheelchair following a series of strokes, and could not attend a public event. The Center instead chose to pay special tribute to him at the 1987 Gala. He died in 1989.<ref>Molotsky, Irvin.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE7DF1031F934A35751C1A961948260 "Five Receive Kennedy Center Honors for Artistic Contributions"] ''The New York Times'' , December 7, 1987</ref>
[[Paul McCartney]] was selected as an honoree in 2002, but was unable to attend because of an "inescapable personal obligation," his cousin's previously planned wedding. After initially saying that McCartney's award would be postponed until the following year, the Kennedy Center announced in August 2003 that "Paul McCartney will not be receiving a Kennedy Center Honor."<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A06EFD61E3EF935A3575BC0A9659C8B63 "The Kennedy Center Honors: This Year's Bid for Glamour"] ''The New York Times'', August 6, 2003</ref> McCartney later became a 2010 honoree.<ref name=george>Trescott, Jacqueline.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/07/AR2010090702439.html "Oprah Winfrey among five recipients of 2010 Kennedy Center Honors"] ''The Washington Post'', September 7, 2010</ref>
[[Mel Brooks]] has stated that he refused the honor when [[George W. Bush]] was in office, due to his distaste for Bush's Iraq policy, but Brooks was an honoree in 2009, the first year Barack Obama was President.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2012/11/mel-brooks-interview.html|title=Mel Brooks on His New Box Set and the 1 Million Great Stories That Come With It|date=13 November 2012|publisher=Vulture}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/05/20/182609040/mel-brooks-i-m-an-egot-so-i-don-t-need-any-more|title=Mel Brooks: 'I'm An EGOT; I Don't Need Any More'|publisher=NPR}}</ref>
In November 2015, one month before the actual ceremony, the Eagles postponed their honors until the following year because Glenn Frey had intestinal problems that required major surgery and a long recovery period.<ref name=eagles/> Despite their absence, they were still honored in 2015 via a performance of "[[Desperado (Eagles song)|Desperado]]" by country singer [[Miranda Lambert]]. Glenn Frey died on January 18, 2016,<ref>{{cite news|last=Morton|first=Victor|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/jan/18/glenn-frey-eagles-guitarist-dies-67/|title=Glenn Frey, Eagles guitarist, dies at 67|work=[[The Washington Times]]|date=January 18, 2016|accessdate=January 18, 2016}}</ref> though the Center made him and the three surviving members 2016 honorees.<ref name="Frey" />
In 2017, [[Norman Lear]] announced that he would accept the honors, but would boycott the White House ceremony because of his opposition to President [[Donald Trump]], citing Trump's proposal to end the [[National Endowment for the Humanities]] and the [[National Endowment for the Arts]].<ref>[https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/08/05/541812555/norman-lear-kennedy-center-honoree-to-skip-white-house-reception-in-protest "Protest"] npr.com, August 5, 2017</ref> Lear did attend the 2017 events and ceremony, but Donald and Melania Trump were not present, becoming the first U.S. presidential couple to skip the event, in order "to allow the honorees to celebrate without any political distraction".<ref name=2017gala/>
==See also== * [[Mark Twain Prize for American Humor]], the Kennedy Center's award for contributions to American humor
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.kennedy-center.org/programs/specialevents/honors}} * [http://www.paleycenter.org/collection/?q=Kennedy%20Center%20Honors&p=1 "Collection Kennedy Center Honors" The Paley Center for Media]

revision.text:
[[Image:Pingret - Louis de Clermont, seigneur de Bussy d'Amboise.jpg|thumb|right|Portrait of Louis de Bussy d'Amboise by [[Édouard Pingret]], 1835]] '''Louis de Clermont, seigneur de Bussy d'Amboise''' (1549–1579) was a gentleman at the court of French king [[Henry III of France|Henri III]], a swordsman, dandy, and a lover of both sexes. He was one of the [[favourite]]s, or "[[Les Mignons|mignons]]", of ''[[François, Duke of Anjou|Monsieur]]'', brother of the king.<ref>''Régistre-journal d'un curieux etc. pendant le règne de Henri III: 1574-1589'' by [[Pierre de L'Estoile]], Jean-Jacques Champollion-Figeac; p. 93</ref> He was a cousin of [[François d'Amboise]].
Of a noble family ([[Georges II d'Amboise|his great-uncle]] was a cardinal), he entered the service of Prince [[François, Duke of Anjou]], the younger brother and rival of Henri III. Bussy became well-known at court as Anjou's "favourite" and later became the lover of Princess [[Marguerite de Valois]].
"Le brave Bussy" made fun of the favourites of the king and frequently fought [[duel]]s with them. He helped Anjou flee from the court where Henri III held him prisoner.
He was a main participant in the [[St. Bartholomew's Day massacre]] (1572), when he assassinated, among others, his relative Antoine de Clermont. While later attempting to seduce the wife of Charles de Chambes, Count of [[Château de Montsoreau|Montsoreau]], he was trapped and killed by her husband.
== In popular culture == Bussy d'Amboise is the hero of the play ''[[Bussy D'Ambois]]'' (1607) by English playwright [[George Chapman]], written 20 years after d'Amboise's death. He is also the hero of the novel ''[[La Dame de Monsoreau]]'' by [[Alexandre Dumas, père]].
[[David R. Slavitt]] featured d'Amboise in his 2011 novel ''The Duke's Man''.
==Notes== <references/>
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Amboise, Louis de Bussy d'}} [[Category:1549 births]] [[Category:1579 deaths]] [[Category:Alexandre Dumas characters]] [[Category:Duellists]] [[Category:House of Amboise|Louis de Bussy d'Amboise]] [[Category:LGBT people from France]] [[Category:LGBT Roman Catholics]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Oluwaseyi Abiodun Makinde |image = 001 Seyi Makinde at LSE Africa Summit.jpg |image_size = |alt = |caption =Seyi Makinde at LSE Africa Summit |birth_name = Oluwaseyi Abiodun Makinde |birth_date = 25 December 1967 |birth_place = [[Ibadan]] |death_date = |death_place = |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = [[Nigeria]]n |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = Group Managing Director of Makon Group Limited |education = |alma_mater = |employer = |occupation = Engineer, Politician |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |title = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Tamunominini |partner = |children = 3 |parents = |relations = |awards = |signature = |website = |footnotes = }}
'''Oluwaseyi Abiodun Makinde''' (born 25 December 1967) is a Nigerian businessman, politician and philanthropist from [[Ibadan]], [[Oyo State]] in South-western [[Nigeria]].<ref name="ALL">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Nigeria: Makinde - Profile of Oyo Guber PDP Aspirant | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''allafrica.com''| date =21 September 2014 | url =http://allafrica.com/stories/201409220019.html | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref> He is an Engineer and a subject matter expert on fluid and Gas Metering.<ref name="TNATION2">{{cite news | last =BISI | first =OLADELE | title =Oyo 2015: Four Ibadan indigenes for governor | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Nation Online NG''| date =23 December 2015 | url =http://thenationonlineng.net/oyo-2015-four-ibadan-indigenes-governor/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref> He is the Group Managing Director of Makon Group Limited; an indigenous oil and gas company in Nigeria.<ref name="TBY">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =TBY talks to Oluseyi Makinde, Group Managing Director of Makon Group, on the Nigerian Content Act, collaborating with partners, and the transforming regulatory landscape. | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Business Year ''| date = | url =https://www.thebusinessyear.com/nigeria-2015/model-operation/interview | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="TNV">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =MAKON'S DAY OF GLORY | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Nigerian Voice''| date = | url =http://www.thenigerianvoice.com/news/51306/1/makons-day-of-glory.html | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref> He established his first oil and gas private business called Makon Engineering and Technical Services, (METS) at the age of 29 in the year 1997, after earning years of work experience with international oil and gas companies.<ref name="ALL"/>
Makinde contested for the Oyo State 2015 gubernatorial seat on the platform [[Social Democratic Party (Nigeria)|Social Democratic Party]] (SDP).<ref name="INFO">{{cite news | last =Daniel | first = | title =Oyo SDP Gov Candidate Pledges To Donate Salary To Teachers Pension If Elected | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''informationng.com''| date =28 January 2015 | url =http://www.informationng.com/2015/01/oyo-sdp-gov-candidate-pledges-to-donate-salary-to-teachers-pension-if-elected.html | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="PUNCH">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =I will lead by example –Olubadan | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Punch Nigeria''| date =18 March 2016 | url =http://www.punchng.com/i-will-lead-by-example-olubadan/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="PTIMES">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Court fixes March 23 for suit against Oyo SDP guber candidate | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''Premium Times''| date =10 March 2015 | url =http://www.premiumtimesng.com/regional/ssouth-west/178241-court-fixes-march-23-for-suit-against-oyo-sdp-guber-candidate.html | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="PUN">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =2015 candidates one year after | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Punch Nigeria''| date =10 April 2016 | url =http://www.punchng.com/2015-candidates-one-year-after/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="TNATION">{{cite news | last =JEREMIAH | first =OKE | title =What next for Seyi Makinde? | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Nation Online NG''| date =27 July 2015 | url =http://thenationonlineng.net/what-next-for-seyi-makinde/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Makinde was born to a renowned teacher turned accountant; late Pa Olatubosun Makinde and Madam Abigail Makinde of Aigbofa Compound in Oja’ba, Ibadan. He is the third child of the family.<ref name="ALL"/><ref name="TNATION2"/>
Makinde began his education at St Paul Primary School and completed his primary education at St Michael Primary School, Yemetu, Ibadan. His secondary education was at Bishop Phillips Academy, Monatan, Ibadan. In 1985, he gained admission to the [[University of Lagos]] (Unilag) where he earned his bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering.
In 1998, Oluwaseyi trained at Industrial Control Services in [[Houston]], [[Texas]] on ''Safety Shutdown System''; and ''Development of Analytical Competence for Managing Operations'' at [[Lagos Business School]] (now [[Pan-Atlantic University]])in 1999.<ref name="MM">{{cite news | last = Olu | first = Kola | title =Students promise support for Makinde | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''m.marketpressrelease.com''| date =27 February 2015 | url =http://m.marketpressrelease.com/pr.php?id=1422948092 | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref> In 2000, he had training in automation. In 2002, he studied Fundamentals of Crude Sampling at Jiskoot Auto Control Training Centre, [[Kent]], [[England]].<ref name="MM"/> Also, in 2005, he studied Understanding and Solving Complex Business Problems at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT), [[United States|USA]].<ref name="MM"/>
==Professional and business career== Makinde did his national service ([[National Youth Service Corps|NYSC]]) with [[Shell Nigeria|Shell Petroleum Development Company]] (SPDC) of Nigeria, where he was later engaged as a pupil engineer. He served in different capacities; handling and partaking in several key projects between 1990 and 1992.<ref name="TNATION2"/> From 1992 to 1997, he worked as a field Engineer ([[Eket]] operations) for Rebold International Limited and in 1995, he was appointed as Field Manager in the same company.<ref name="TNATION2"/>
In 1997, Makinde established his first business, Makon Engineering and Technical Services Limited (METS), after working for five years (1992-1997) with various international oil and gas companies (IOCs), as the Engineering Manager. He is now the Group Managing Director of Makon Group of Companies.<ref name="TBY"/><ref name="TNV"/>
Makinde is a member of national and international professional bodies notably: [[Nigerian Society of Chemical Engineers|Nigerian Society of Engineers]] (NSE), ''Council for Regulations of Engineering in Nigeria''(COREN), ''Oil and Gas Design Engineers of Nigeria (OGDEN)'', [[International Society of Automation]] (ISA), [[Institute of Measurement and Control]] UK; and American Measurement Institute (AMI).<ref name="ALL"/><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Makinde’s emergence under SDP divine Ayoola | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''marketpressrelease.com''| date =9 March 2015 | url =http://www.marketpressrelease.com/Makindes-emergence-under-SDP-divine-Ayoola-1424946462.html | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref>
==Political career== In 2007, Makinde contested for the Oyo South Senatorial seat under the platform of the [[All Nigeria Peoples Party]] (ANPP) but lost to the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People’s Democratic Party]] candidate- Kamoru Adedibu.<ref name="TNATION"/> Makinde remained undeterred by his first failed attempt and in 2010; under the People’s Democratic Party, PDP, he aspired for the Oyo South 2011 Senatorial seat but lost the primary to the incumbent Oyo South Senator.<ref name="TNATION"/><ref name="LEAD">{{cite news | last =Adebayo | first =Waheed | title =Makinde Rejects Oyo PDP Guber Primary Result | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''leadership.ng''| date =11 December 2014 | url =http://leadership.ng/news/394367/makinde-rejects-oyo-pdp-guber-primary-result | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="TSJ">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Oyo Guber Hopeful, Seyi Makinde Berates Gov Ajimobi over Campaign Office Raid | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Street Journal''| date =20 March 2014 | url =http://thestreetjournal.org/2014/03/oyo-guber-hopeful-seyi-makinde-berates-gov-ajimobi-over-campaign-office-raid/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="TSJ2">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Oyo Gov: Seyi Makinde Dumps PDP, Joins SDP | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''The Street Journal''| date =15 December 2014 | url =http://thestreetjournal.org/2014/12/oyo-gov-seyi-makinde-dumps-pdp-joins-sdp/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref>
In 2014, Makinde aimed for the Oyo State 2015 governorship ticket under the platform of the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]] (PDP). In December 2014, upon the conclusion of the party’s primary election, he was denied the governorship nomination ticket.<ref name="SP">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Oyo NASU to build N500m office complex | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''sundiatapost.com''| date = | url =http://sundiatapost.com/2014/06/03/oyo-nasu-to-build-n500m-office-complex/#/jobs?ref=Sundiata&page=1&count=5&use_ng=1 | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="TN">{{cite news | last =BISI | first =OLADELE | title =Can PDP/Accord merger work in Oyo? | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''thenationonlineng.net''| date =25 April 2016 | url =http://thenationonlineng.net/can-pdpaccord-merger-work-oyo/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref><ref name="LN">{{cite news | last =Adebayo | first =Waheed | title =Oyo 2015: PDP Has Not Anointed Any Candidate – Makinde | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''leadership.ng''| date =10 November 2014 | url =http://leadership.ng/news/389895/oyo-2015-pdp-anointed-candidate-makinde | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref> Makinde however, remained true to his ambition and defected to the Social Democratic Party (SDP), under which platform he contested for the Oyo State 2015 SDP gubernatorial candidate, but lost out in the end.<ref name="LN"/>
In September 2017, the Caretaker National Chairman of PDP, Senator [[Ahmed Makarfi]] visited him in Ibadan and following extensive, deep and wide consultations with National Leaders, Oyo State leaders and elders of the Social Democratic Party, and cross sections of strategic partners within Oyo State, Engineer Seyi Makinde returned to his former political party, [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]] (PDP). He maintained that joining the PDP was not for personal gains but for the development of the State by finding lasting solutions to the array of problems facing the State.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Seyi Makinde Rejoins PDP from SDP in Oyo-State | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''vanguardngr.com''| date =| url =http://community.vanguardngr.com/forum/topics/seyi-makinde-rejoins-pdp-from-sdp-in-oyo-state?xg_source=activity | accessdate =9 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Oyo SDP governorship candidate, Seyi Makinde returns to PDP | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''dailypost.ng''| date =4 September 2017| url =http://dailypost.ng/2017/09/04/oyo-sdp-governorship-candidate-seyi-makinde-returns-pdp/ | accessdate =9 February 2018}}</ref>
On September 29, 2018, Makinde emerged as the gubernatorial candidate of the [[People`s Democratic Party (Nigeria)| People's Democratic Party]] (PDP) for the 2019 general elections for [[Oyo State]], after polling 2772 votes at the primary election that took place at liberty stadium,Oke Ado in Ibadan.<ref>http://dailypost.ng/2018/09/30/breaking-oyo-2019-seyi-makinde-emerges-pdp-gubernatorial-candidate-photos/amp/</ref>
==Awards and recognitions== * Nigerian Union of Journalists (Oyo State Council)-Laudable Contribution to Humanity Merit Award.<ref name="TAN">{{cite news | last = | first = | title =CCII Honours Seyi Makinde, Others | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''theanchoronline.com.ng''| date =17 March 2016 | url =http://theanchoronline.com.ng/ccii-honours-seyi-makinde-others/ | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref> * National Association of Oke-Ogun Students (Ibadan)-Merit Award.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Ogunmola bags FNOOS award | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''heritageechonews.blogspot.com.ng''| date =18 April 2014 | url =http://heritageechonews.blogspot.com.ng/2014/04/ogunmola-bags-fnoos-award.html | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref> * Fiditi Grammar School (Oyo State)-Old Student Merit Award in appreciation to the commitment, dedication and service to the association and humanity.<ref name="ALL"/> * Junior Chamber International (JCI) University of Calabar Chapter.-Entrepreneurial Excellence Award.<ref name="ALL"/> * Sports Writers Association of Nigeria (Oyo State Chapter)-Gold Merit Award for immense and invaluable contribution to sports development.<ref name="ALL"/> * Nigerian Association of Social Workers Merit Awards (Oyo State Chapter)-Philanthropic gestures and contribution to Social Care Delivery Services.<ref name="ALL"/> * CCII National Merit Award.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Glo, CCII paint Ibadan green •As CCII honours Makinde, Olujinmi, others | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''tribuneonlineng.com''| date =17 March 2016 | url =http://www.tribuneonlineng.com/glo-ccii-paint-ibadan-green-%E2%80%A2as-ccii-honours-makinde-olujinmi-others | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref>
* [[Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria]] (Ibadan) - awarded Seyi "Astute Politician of the Year 2018" for his resilience with which he had continued to assist the less privileged in the society.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =FRCN Xmas Grand Finale: Seyi Makinde Felicitates with Kids | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''radionigeriaibadan.org.ng''| date =23 December 2017| url =http://www.radionigeriaibadan.org.ng/2017/12/23/frcn-xmas-grand-finale-seyi-makinde-felicitates-with-kids/ | accessdate =9 February 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Oluwaseyi lives in Ibadan, Oyo State. He is married to Tamunominini, and they have three children.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title =Meet Seyi Makinde | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''seyimakinde4governor.com''| date =| url =http://www.seyimakinde4governor.com/meet-seyi-makinde.htm | accessdate =21 May 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Makinde, Oluwaseyi}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Nigerian people]] [[Category:Nigerian chief executives]] [[Category:Nigerian politicians]] [[Category:Politicians from Ibadan]] [[Category:Yoruba politicians]] [[Category:University of Lagos alumni]] [[Category:Pan-Atlantic University alumni]]

{{Infobox person | name = Philippa Perry | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Philippa Fairclough | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1957}} | birth_place = [[Warrington]], [[Lancashire]], England | occupation = Psychotherapy, journalism | alma_mater = [[Middlesex Polytechnic]] | works = ''How to Stay Sane'' | spouse = [[Grayson Perry]] | children = 1 }} '''Philippa Perry''' (née Fairclough; born 1957) is a British [[psychotherapist]] and the author of the graphic novel, ''Couch Fiction; a graphic tale of psychotherapy'' (2010),<ref name="Couch">{{cite book | last = Perry | first = Philippa | others = Junko Gratt (illustrator) | title = Couch fiction: a graphic tale of psychotherapy | publisher = Palgrave Macmillan | location = Hampshire, England New York | year = 2010 | isbn = 9780230366220 }}</ref> and ''How to Stay Sane'' (2012).<ref name="How">{{cite book | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = How to stay sane | publisher = Picador | location = New York | year = 2013 | isbn = 9781250030641 }}</ref>
==Early life== Philippa Perry was born in [[Warrington]], [[Lancashire]], and educated at boarding school and at a Swiss finishing school.<ref name=cook>{{ cite news |last = Cooke | first = Rachel | author-link = Rachel Cooke |url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2010/apr/18/philippa-parry-couch-fiction-interview | title= I love Susie Orbach and Harvey Pekar comics – so I wrote Couch Fiction, a comic book about psychotherapy|page=13|work= [[The Observer]] |date= 18 April 2010|location=London}}</ref>
She worked as a litigation clerk, an enquiry agent, and a McDonald's employee. She went to [[Middlesex Polytechnic]] where she gained a degree in [[Fine Art]] as a mature student.<ref>{{cite news |last = Randall | first = L. |url=http://living.scotsman.com/books/Interview-Philippa-Perry--Writer.6266104.jp|title=Interview: Philippa Perry - Writer|work=[[The Scotsman]]|location=Edinburgh|date=30 April 2010}}</ref>
==Work== In 1985 she trained and volunteered for the [[Samaritans (charity)|Samaritans]], after which she trained as a psychotherapist. Perry worked in the mental health field for 20 years, ten in private practice, before being published.<ref name=cook /> In 2010 she joined the faculty of the School of Life.<ref>{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://www.theschooloflife.com/london/about-us/about-us |website=theschooloflife.com |publisher=School of Life}}</ref>
She had a regular column about psychotherapy in ''[[Psychologies|Psychologies Magazine]]''<ref>{{cite news | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = Twitter chat: your mother and you | url = https://www.psychologies.co.uk/twitter-chat-your-mother-and-you | work = [[Psychologies|Psychologies Magazine]] | publisher = [[Lagardère Active]] | date = 16 May 2012 }}</ref> for two years; in September 2013 she became ''Red Magazine'''s agony aunt.<ref name="Red">{{cite news |last=Gilchrist|first=Hannah | title= Tell us your dilemmas | url = http://www.redonline.co.uk/red-women/blogs/philippa-perry-red-magazine-agony-aunt | work = [[Hearst (media)#Magazines|Red (magazine)]] | publisher = [[Hearst (media)|Hearst]] | date = 2 September 2013 }}</ref> She also works as a freelance journalist specialising in psychology and was an occasional presenter for ''[[The Culture Show]]'' on [[BBC Two]].
Perry has presented various documentaries including: ''Sex Lies and Lovebites: The Agony Aunt Story'' ([[BBC Four]]);<ref>{{cite AV media |people= Philippa Perry (presenter) |date= 6 May 2016 |title= Sex Lies and Lovebites |medium= Television |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0555vjj |access-date= 20 February 2017 |publisher=[[BBC Four]] }}</ref> ''Being BiPolar'' ([[Channel 4]]);<ref>{{cite AV media |people=Philippa Perry (presenter) |date= 4 March 2015 |title= Being BiPolar |medium= Television|url= http://www.channel4.com/programmes/being-bipolar |access-date= 20 February 2017 |publisher=[[Channel 4]] }}</ref> ''The Truth About Children Who Lie'' ([[BBC Radio 4]]);<ref>{{cite AV media |people= Philippa Perry (presenter) |date= 23 August 2016 |title= The Truth About Children Who Lie |medium=Television |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p045xft6 |access-date= 20 February 2017|publisher= [[BBC Radio 4]] }}</ref> and ''The Great British Sex Survey'' ([[Channel 4]]).<ref>{{cite AV media |people=Philippa Perry (presenter) and Goedele Liekens (presenter) |date= 25 February 2016 |title= The Great British Sex Survey |medium= Television|url= http://www.channel4.com/info/press/news/channel-4-to-reveal-the-no-1-fetish-in-the-great-british-sex-survey |access-date= 20 February 2017 |publisher=[[Channel 4]] }}</ref>
==Politics== In April 2016 Perry announced her support for the [[Women's Equality Party]].<ref name=Half>{{cite AV media | people= [[Catherine Mayer]], [[Lily Allen]], Ninotchka, [[Hugh Quarshie]], [[Stella Duffy]], [[Tanya Moodie]], Philippa Perry, [[Jack Monroe]] and Leila Bertrand | date= 27 April 2016 | accessdate= 28 April 2016 | title= Give half your votes to equality on 5 May - WE think that's fair #VoteWE | medium= Video | publisher= Women's Equality Channel via [[YouTube]] | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0n-6pT0_uso }}</ref>
==Publications==
;Books In 2010 the academic publisher, Palgrave Macmillan, published Perry's book, ''Couch Fiction: a graphic tale of psychotherapy''.<ref name="Couch" /> It is a graphic novel that tells a tale of a psychotherapist and her client, from both their perspectives. Underneath the graphic novel boxes, Perry takes the position of commentator and provides footnotes on what might be going on between them and what theories the therapist is drawing on or should be drawing on. There is an afterword by Professor [[Andrew Samuels]].
''How to Stay Sane'', published by Pan Macmillan May, 2012<ref name="How" /><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/apr/06/alain-de-botton-philosophical-self-help | location=London | work=[[The Guardian]] | first=Benedicte | last=Page | title=Alain de Botton launches series of 'philosophical' self-help books | date=6 April 2011}}</ref> The School of Life Self Help Series edited by [[Alain de Botton]].
;Various articles including: * {{Cite journal | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = Working with dissociation | journal = The British Journal of Psychotherapy Integration, special issue: Integrative Practice with an Emphasis on Working with Trauma | volume = 4 | issue = 2 | pages = 29-42 | publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]] | date = 2007 | url = http://www.ukapi.com/journal/ | issn = 1759-0000 | ref = harv | postscript = . | deadurl = bot: unknown | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160627052207/http://www.ukapi.com/journal/ | archivedate = 2016-06-27 | df = }} [http://www.ukapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/journal42.pdf Preview.] * {{Cite journal | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = Relational marketing? | journal = The British Journal of Psychotherapy Integration, special issue: Aspect of the Integrative Endeavour | volume = 6 | issue = 2 | pages = 47-51 | publisher = [[Palgrave Macmillan]] | date = 2009 | url = http://www.ukapi.com/journal/ | issn = 1759-0000 | ref = harv | postscript = . | deadurl = bot: unknown | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160627052207/http://www.ukapi.com/journal/ | archivedate = 2016-06-27 | df = }} [http://www.ukapi.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/journal62.pdf Preview.] * {{cite news | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = How to be happy: a psychotherapst's view | url = https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2011/jan/18/how-to-be-happy-psychotherapist | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 18 January 2011}} * {{cite news | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = Ideas for modern living: chemistry | url = https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/may/02/school-of-life-chemistry-philippa-perry | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 2 May 2010 }} * {{cite news | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = Gender and the tyranny of the normal | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/feb/23/gender-dysphoria-tyranny-of-normal | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 23 February 2012 }} * {{cite news | last = Perry | first = Philippa | title = Why children kill their parents | url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/apr/03/why-children-kill-parents | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 3 April 2012 }}
Perry is a monthly Agony Aunt for ''[[Hearst (media)#Magazines|Red]]'' (magazine).<ref name="Red" />
==Personal life== She is married to artist and cross-dresser [[Grayson Perry]], and they have a daughter, Florence, born in 1992. The Perrys live in London.{{cn|date=May 2017}} She has often been asked what it is like being married to a transvestite and says, "Being the wife of a trannie is great, he always makes me look fantastic".<ref>{{cite news|last=Wynne Jones|first=Ros|title =Grayson Perry on cross dressing and happiness as "Britain's pre-eminent transvestite"|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/grayson-perry-cross-dressing-happiness-4479815|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=13 December 2003}}</ref> When asked the same question by a Buckingham Palace Press Officer when the Perrys went to a reception there in 2005, she said, "As obsessions go, it's better than football".<ref>{{cite news | last = Macdonald | first = Marianne|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/3637220/Just-a-sweet-transvestite.html|title=Just a sweet transvestite|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|Daily Telegraph]]|date=16 February 2005|location=London}}</ref>
==References== <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|30em}}

A '''press agent''', or '''flack''',<ref name="mw">[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/flack Merriam-Webster: flack]</ref> is a professional [[publicist]] who acts on behalf of his or her client on all matters involving [[public relations]]. Press agents are typically employed by public personalities and organizations such as [[performer]]s and businesses. A press agent will provide information to the media such as upcoming public events, interview opportunities, and promotional dates, and will work with the [[Mass media|media]] in getting in touch with an appropriate client or resource. Press agents are occasionally required to act as "[[spin doctor]]s" – to put into the best light their clients' public actions. While press agents have traditionally worked with newspapers and television, they may also be conversant with newer media forms such as [[blog]]s and [[podcast]]s.
==See also== * [[Spokesperson]]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Public relations people by role]]
{{Job-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} {{italic title}} '''''Puss 'n' Boots''''' was a British comic strip which ran in the UK comic magazine ''[[Sparky (comic)|Sparky]]'' from 1969 to 1977 and later appeared in ''[[Topper (comic book)|Topper]]'' and ''[[The Dandy]]''. Most of the strips were drawn by [[John Geering]]. Some scripts were written by Morris Heggie, later to become editor of the Dandy.
==Concept==
The strip's protagonists are Puss, a black anthropomorphic [[cat]] and Boots, a similarly humanoid brown [[dog]]. In the stories they are in a continuous state of conflict, as indicated by the strap-line "They Fight Like Cat and Dog". Most stories revolved around one of them playing a trick on the other, the recipient getting revenge and both fighting. The strip name is a pun on the pantomime ''[[Puss in Boots]]''.
It was one of a few [[D. C. Thomson & Co.|DC Thomson ]] cartoons where dialogue was as important as the artwork, with Puss and Boots insulting each other elaborately.
Regular characters included Puss' baby nephew, Titch, whose speech largely consisted of the word 'Baggle', and from time to time the Scottish uncles, Uncle Hamish McToorie and Uncle Duncan McTavish.
==Later history==
As its sales faltered ''Sparky'' was merged with ''Topper'' which also failed. From 1993 ''Puss 'n' Boots'' appeared infrequently in the Dandy before a long hiatus. The artist John Geering died in 1999. The strip ran in ''The Dandy'' for two spells in the early 2000s, drawn by [[Barrie Appleby]], who also drew [[Cuddles and Dimples]], before being dropped when the comic was revamped in October 2004.
From 2008 new strips appeared in ''The Dandy'' and older strips were reprinted in [[Classics from the Comics]]. ''Puss 'n' Boots'' appear in the Dandy Annual 2009, drawn by [[Nigel Parkinson]]. They also feature in the 2012 annual drawn by [[Nigel Auchterlounie]].
A similarly themed strip also appeared in [[The Beano]] under the name [[Meebo and Zuky]].
==See also== {{Reflist}}
{{Dandy|Puss 'n' Boots (Sparky comics)}} {{D. C. Thomson Comics}}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category People associated with the Metropolitan Opera to [[:Category:Metropolitan Opera people]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 3]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} [[File:Rosina Galli 2 - Dec 1919 Shadowland.jpg|thumbnail|Rosina Galli]]
'''Rosina Galli''' (1892 – April 30, 1940) was an Italian [[ballet dancer]], choreographer, ballet mistress,<ref>{{cite book|title=Opera News|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kvg6OaMCBSMC|year=1962|publisher=Metropolitan Opera Guild|page=278}}</ref> and dance teacher. After early years in Italy, she moved to the US, where she was associated with the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in New York City. [[Prima ballerina]] at [[La Scala Theatre Ballet]],<ref name="LaGuminaCavaioli2013">{{cite book|last1=LaGumina|first1=Salvatore J.|last2=Cavaioli|first2=Frank J.|last3=Primeggia|first3=Salvatore|author4=Joseph A. Varacalli|title=Italian American Experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JUyAAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA165|date=21 August 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-58333-0|pages=165–}}</ref> and the [[Chicago Ballet]], she was also the [[List of prima ballerinas|''première danseuse'']] at the [[Teatro di San Carlo]] and the Metropolitan Opera.<ref name=Galli1919>{{cite journal|last=Galli|first=Rosina|title=My Life as a Ballet-Dancer|journal=The Forum|date=July 1919|pages=11–20|url=http://www.unz.org/Pub/Forum-1919jul-00011|accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref>
==Biography== [[File:Rosina Galli - Feb 1920 Shadowland.jpg|thumbnail|upright|left|Galli (1920)]] Galli was born in Naples, where her father was a lawyer. She studied dance at the [[Teatro di San Carlo]]'s ballet school, becoming the company's ''première danseuse'' at the age of 14.<ref name="nytimes1911">{{cite news|title=Seventeen-Year-Old Dancer Delights Operagoers|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1911/11/12/104882406.pdf|accessdate=23 February 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 November 1911}}</ref> When she was offered the première danseuse position at La Scala Theatre Ballet, the family moved to Milan. She debuted in 1910, at the age of eighteen, dancing in ''Pietro Micca'' and ''Ballo Excelsior'' of [[Luigi Manzotti]].
In 1911, her father and two brothers escorted Galli to [[Genoa]], from where Galli and her mother proceeded to [[Chicago]], US. Galli performed first as soloist,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chujoy|first1=Anatole|last2=Manchester|first2=P W|title=The Dance Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xujdtusdm8YC|year=1967|publisher=Simon and Schuster |location=New York|page=394}}</ref> and then as prima ballerina of the Chicago Ballet. In 1913,<ref name="D'Acierno1999">{{cite book|last=D'Acierno|first=Pellegrino|title=The Italian American Heritage: A Companion to Literature and Arts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nevq7gnw-WgC&pg=PA470|date=January 1999|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-8153-0380-0|pages=470–}}</ref> she was hired by the Metropolitan Opera House. Though she sported a petite figure, characterized as [[elf]]ish, Galli demonstrated a rigorous technique and performed powerful [[pirouette]]s, continuing to dance there until 1931.<ref name=LaGuminaCavaioli2013 /> Her partner at the Met was Giuseppe Bonfiglio.<ref name="CohenFoundation1998">{{cite book|last1=Cohen|first1=Selma Jeanne|author2=Dance Perspectives Foundation|title=International encyclopedia of dance: a project of Dance Perspectives Foundation, Inc|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nhsKAQAAMAAJ|year=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-512308-1|page=382}}</ref> Her studies in America were under [[Luigi Albertieri]].<ref name="PageWentink1984">{{cite book|last1=Page|first1=Ruth|last2=Wentink|first2=Andrew Mark|last3=Delfau|first3=André|title=Class: notes on dance classes around the world, 1915–1980|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V098U1gISR4C|year=1984|publisher=Princeton Book Co.|page=35}}</ref>
In 1919, she began teaching dance at the Met, also serving as ballet mistress until 1935.<ref name="D'Acierno1999" /> As a teacher, she applied the strict program from her days at La Scala, teaching the [[Cecchetti method]].<ref name="Duberman2008">{{cite book|last=Duberman|first=Martin|title=The Worlds of Lincoln Kirstein|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eR8JMsUFVEcC&pg=PA209|date=25 September 2008|publisher=Northwestern University Press|isbn=978-0-8101-2518-6|pages=209–}}</ref> [[Helen Tamiris]], who formed the School of American Dance in 1930, was a pupil under Galli.<ref name="JacksonKeller2010">{{cite book|last1=Jackson|first1=Kenneth T.|last2=Keller|first2=Lisa|last3=Flood|first3=Nancy|title=The Encyclopedia of New York City: Second Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lI5ERUmHf3YC&pg=PT5959|date=1 December 2010|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-18257-6|pages=5959–}}</ref> Her expanded responsibilities included choreography, and in that respect, Galli is credited for over 100 offerings at the Met,<ref>{{cite web|title=Galli, Rosina [Choreographer]|url=http://archives.metoperafamily.org/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WService=BibSpeed/gisrch2k.r?Term=Galli,+Rosina+[Choreographer]&limit=500&vsrchtype=no&xBranch=ALL&xmtype&Start&End&theterm=Galli,+Rosina+[Choreographer]&srt&x=0&xHome&xHomePath|publisher=Met Opera|accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref> such as ''[[Carmen]]'' (1924),<ref>{{cite web|title=Carmen {292} Metropolitan Opera House: 26 November 1924|url=http://archives.metoperafamily.org/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WService=BibSpeed/fullcit.w?xCID=88290|publisher=Met Opera|accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref> ''[[La traviata]]'' (1925),<ref>{{cite web|title=La Traviata {130} Metropolitan Opera House: 13 February 1925|url=http://archives.metoperafamily.org/archives/scripts/cgiip.exe/WService=BibSpeed/fullcit.w?xCID=89360|publisher=Met Opera|accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref> and ''[[Merry Mount (opera)|Merry Mount]]'' (1934).<ref>{{cite web|title=Merry Mount|url=http://www.operaamerica.org/applications/nawd/newworks/details.aspx?id=569|publisher=Opera America|accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref>
It was at the Met where Galli met her future husband, [[Giulio Gatti-Casazza]], former superintendent at La Scala and director of the Met since 1908. Initially she was his mistress;<ref name="Ostwald1991">{{cite book|last=Ostwald|first=Peter F.|title=Vaslav Nijinsky: A Leap Into Madness|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1VNuCYaauZUC&pg=PA136|date=January 1991|publisher=Carol Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-8184-0535-8|pages=136–}}</ref><ref name="Fiedler2003">{{cite book|last=Fiedler|first=Johanna|title=Molto Agitato: The Mayhem Behind the Music at the Metropolitan Opera|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v9gtOoMw8RAC&pg=PT30|date=9 September 2003|publisher=Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4000-7589-8|pages=30–}}</ref> they married in 1930 at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in [[Jersey City, New Jersey]].<ref name=Fitchburg1930>{{cite news|title=Company Dancer|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/45634254/|accessdate=23 February 2014|newspaper=Fitchburg Sentinel|date=19 June 1930}}</ref> When her husband retired in 1935, the couple returned to Italy, residing at a villa on [[Lake Maggiore]].<ref name="Taubman1994">{{cite book|last=Taubman|first=Howard|title=The Pleasure of Their Company: A Reminiscence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=djQ1hiZU1tEC&pg=PA251|year=1994|publisher=Amadeus Press|isbn=978-0-931340-78-9|pages=251–}}</ref> She died in Milan on April 30, 1940. Gatti, 23 years older, died the following September. <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="5"> File:Rosina Galli 3 - Dec 1919 Shadowland.jpg|Galli (1919) Image:Rosina Galli.jpg|Italian dancer and choreographer Rosina Galli File:Rosina Galli4.jpg|Giuseppe Bonfiglio and Rosina Galli in costume for the Polovtsian Dances in Borodin's "Prince Igor " 1915
File:Rosina Galli3.jpg </gallery>
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==Sources== * Tullia Bohen Limarzi, ''She Trills with Her Toes. The Metropolitan Ballet Career of Rosina Galli'', in: ''Proceedings of the 9th Annual Conference of the Dance History Scholars'', pp. 80–90, 1986 * "Galli Rosina", in: Felice Cappa, Piero Gelli, Marco Mattarozzi, ''Dizionario dello spettacolo del '900'', [[Baldini & Castoldi]], 1998 {{ISBN|88-8089-295-9}} (p. 442) {{it|icon}} * "Galli Rosina in Gatti Casazza", in: Rachele Farina (a cura di), ''Dizionario biografico delle donne lombarde: 568–1968'', [[Baldini & Castoldi]], 1995 {{ISBN|88-808-9085-9}} (pp. 499–500) {{it|icon}} * Ennio Speranza, ''[[Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani]]'' – Volume 52 (1999), [[Istituto dell'Enciclopedia italiana Treccani]] {{it|icon}}
==External links== *{{commonscat-inline|Rosina Galli}}
